enum.name: GBindingFlags
enum.description:
Flags to be passed to g_object_bind_property() or g_object_bind_property_full().
This enumeration can be extended at later date.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: G_BINDING_DEFAULT
parameter.parameter_description: The default binding; if the source property changes, the target property is updated with its value.

parameter.name: G_BINDING_BIDIRECTIONAL
parameter.parameter_description: Bidirectional binding; if either the property of the source or the property of the target changes, the other is updated.

parameter.name: G_BINDING_SYNC_CREATE
parameter.parameter_description: Synchronize the values of the source and target properties when creating the binding; the direction of the synchronization is always from the source to the target.

parameter.name: G_BINDING_INVERT_BOOLEAN
parameter.parameter_description: If the two properties being bound are booleans, setting one to %TRUE will result in the other being set to %FALSE and vice versa. This flag will only work for boolean properties, and cannot be used when passing custom transformation functions to g_object_bind_property_full().

enum.name: GBookmarkFileError
enum.description: Error codes returned by bookmark file parsing.

parameter.name: G_BOOKMARK_FILE_ERROR_INVALID_VALUE
parameter.parameter_description: a requested field was not found

parameter.name: G_BOOKMARK_FILE_ERROR_APP_NOT_REGISTERED
parameter.parameter_description: a requested application did not register a bookmark

parameter.name: G_BOOKMARK_FILE_ERROR_URI_NOT_FOUND
parameter.parameter_description: a requested URI was not found

parameter.name: G_BOOKMARK_FILE_ERROR_UNKNOWN_ENCODING
parameter.parameter_description: the text being parsed was in an unknown encoding

enum.name: GChecksumType
enum.description:
The hashing algorithm to be used by #GChecksum when performing the digest of some data.
Note that the #GChecksumType enumeration may be extended at a later date to include new hashing algorithm types.
Since: 2.16

enum.name: GConnectFlags
enum.description: The connection flags are used to specify the behaviour of a signal's connection.

parameter.name: G_CONNECT_AFTER
parameter.parameter_description: whether the handler should be called before or after the default handler of the signal.

parameter.name: G_CONNECT_SWAPPED
parameter.parameter_description: whether the instance and data should be swapped when calling the handler; see g_signal_connect_swapped() for an example.

enum.name: GConvertError
enum.description: Error codes returned by character set conversion routines.

parameter.name: G_CONVERT_ERROR_NO_CONVERSION
parameter.parameter_description: Conversion between the requested character sets is not supported.

parameter.name: G_CONVERT_ERROR_ILLEGAL_SEQUENCE
parameter.parameter_description: Invalid byte sequence in conversion input.

parameter.name: G_CONVERT_ERROR_PARTIAL_INPUT
parameter.parameter_description: Partial character sequence at end of input.

parameter.name: G_CONVERT_ERROR_NOT_ABSOLUTE_PATH
parameter.parameter_description: Pathname is not an absolute path.

enum.name: GDateDMY
enum.description: This enumeration isn't used in the API, but may be useful if you need to mark a number as a day, month, or year.

enum.name: GDateMonth
enum.description: Enumeration representing a month; values are #G_DATE_JANUARY, #G_DATE_FEBRUARY, etc. #G_DATE_BAD_MONTH is the invalid value.

enum.name: GDateWeekday
enum.description: Enumeration representing a day of the week; #G_DATE_MONDAY, #G_DATE_TUESDAY, etc. #G_DATE_BAD_WEEKDAY is an invalid weekday.

enum.name: GErrorType
enum.description: The possible errors, used in the @v_error field of #GTokenValue, when the token is a %G_TOKEN_ERROR.

parameter.name: G_ERR_DIGIT_RADIX
parameter.parameter_description: digit beyond radix in a number

enum.name: GFileError
enum.description:
Values corresponding to @errno codes returned from file operations on UNIX. Unlike @errno codes, GFileError values are available on all systems, even Windows. The exact meaning of each code depends on what sort of file operation you were performing; the UNIX documentation gives more details. The following error code descriptions come from the GNU C Library manual, and are under the copyright of that manual.
It's not very portable to make detailed assumptions about exactly which errors will be returned from a given operation. Some errors don't occur on some systems, etc., sometimes there are subtle differences in when a system will report a given error, etc.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_EXIST
parameter.parameter_description: Operation not permitted; only the owner of the file (or other resource) or processes with special privileges can perform the operation.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_ISDIR
parameter.parameter_description: File is a directory; you cannot open a directory for writing, or create or remove hard links to it.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_ACCES
parameter.parameter_description: Permission denied; the file permissions do not allow the attempted operation.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_NOENT
parameter.parameter_description: No such file or directory. This is a "file doesn't exist" error for ordinary files that are referenced in contexts where they are expected to already exist.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_NOTDIR
parameter.parameter_description: A file that isn't a directory was specified when a directory is required.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_NXIO
parameter.parameter_description: No such device or address. The system tried to use the device represented by a file you specified, and it couldn't find the device. This can mean that the device file was installed incorrectly, or that the physical device is missing or not correctly attached to the computer.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_NODEV
parameter.parameter_description: The underlying file system of the specified file does not support memory mapping.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_ROFS
parameter.parameter_description: The directory containing the new link can't be modified because it's on a read-only file system.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_FAULT
parameter.parameter_description: You passed in a pointer to bad memory. (GLib won't reliably return this, don't pass in pointers to bad memory.)

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_LOOP
parameter.parameter_description: Too many levels of symbolic links were encountered in looking up a file name. This often indicates a cycle of symbolic links.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_NOSPC
parameter.parameter_description: No space left on device; write operation on a file failed because the disk is full.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_NOMEM
parameter.parameter_description: No memory available. The system cannot allocate more virtual memory because its capacity is full.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_MFILE
parameter.parameter_description: The current process has too many files open and can't open any more. Duplicate descriptors do count toward this limit.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_NFILE
parameter.parameter_description: There are too many distinct file openings in the entire system.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_BADF
parameter.parameter_description: Bad file descriptor; for example, I/O on a descriptor that has been closed or reading from a descriptor open only for writing (or vice versa).

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_INVAL
parameter.parameter_description: Invalid argument. This is used to indicate various kinds of problems with passing the wrong argument to a library function.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_PIPE
parameter.parameter_description: Broken pipe; there is no process reading from the other end of a pipe. Every library function that returns this error code also generates a 'SIGPIPE' signal; this signal terminates the program if not handled or blocked. Thus, your program will never actually see this code unless it has handled or blocked 'SIGPIPE'.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_AGAIN
parameter.parameter_description: Resource temporarily unavailable; the call might work if you try again later.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_INTR
parameter.parameter_description: Interrupted function call; an asynchronous signal occurred and prevented completion of the call. When this happens, you should try the call again.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_IO
parameter.parameter_description: Input/output error; usually used for physical read or write errors. i.e. the disk or other physical device hardware is returning errors.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_PERM
parameter.parameter_description: Operation not permitted; only the owner of the file (or other resource) or processes with special privileges can perform the operation.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_NOSYS
parameter.parameter_description: Function not implemented; this indicates that the system is missing some functionality.

parameter.name: G_FILE_ERROR_FAILED
parameter.parameter_description: Does not correspond to a UNIX error code; this is the standard "failed for unspecified reason" error code present in all #GError error code enumerations. Returned if no specific code applies.

enum.name: GFileTest
enum.description: A test to perform on a file using g_file_test().

parameter.name: G_FILE_TEST_IS_REGULAR
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the file is a regular file (not a directory). Note that this test will also return %TRUE if the tested file is a symlink to a regular file.

parameter.name: G_FILE_TEST_IS_SYMLINK
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the file is a symlink.

parameter.name: G_FILE_TEST_IS_DIR
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the file is a directory.

parameter.name: G_FILE_TEST_EXISTS
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the file exists. It may or may not be a regular file.

enum.name: GFormatSizeFlags
enum.description: Flags to modify the format of the string returned by g_format_size_full().

parameter.name: G_FORMAT_SIZE_LONG_FORMAT
parameter.parameter_description: include the exact number of bytes as part of the returned string. For example, "45.6 kB (45,612 bytes)".

parameter.name: G_FORMAT_SIZE_IEC_UNITS
parameter.parameter_description: use IEC (base 1024) units with "KiB"-style suffixes. IEC units should only be used for reporting things with a strong "power of 2" basis, like RAM sizes or RAID stripe sizes. Network and storage sizes should be reported in the normal SI units.

enum.name: GHookFlagMask
enum.description: Flags used internally in the #GHook implementation.

parameter.name: G_HOOK_FLAG_ACTIVE
parameter.parameter_description: set if the hook has not been destroyed

parameter.name: G_HOOK_FLAG_IN_CALL
parameter.parameter_description: set if the hook is currently being run

parameter.name: G_HOOK_FLAG_MASK
parameter.parameter_description: A mask covering all bits reserved for hook flags; see %G_HOOK_FLAG_USER_SHIFT

enum.name: GIOChannelError
enum.description: Error codes returned by #GIOChannel operations.

parameter.name: G_IO_CHANNEL_ERROR_OVERFLOW
parameter.parameter_description: Value too large for defined datatype.

enum.name: GIOCondition
enum.description: A bitwise combination representing a condition to watch for on an event source.

parameter.name: G_IO_PRI
parameter.parameter_description: There is urgent data to read.

parameter.name: G_IO_HUP
parameter.parameter_description: Hung up (the connection has been broken, usually for pipes and sockets).

parameter.name: G_IO_NVAL
parameter.parameter_description: Invalid request. The file descriptor is not open.

enum.name: GIOError
enum.description: #GIOError is only used by the deprecated functions g_io_channel_read(), g_io_channel_write(), and g_io_channel_seek().

enum.name: GIOFlags
enum.description: Specifies properties of a #GIOChannel. Some of the flags can only be read with g_io_channel_get_flags(), but not changed with g_io_channel_set_flags().

parameter.name: G_IO_FLAG_APPEND
parameter.parameter_description: turns on append mode, corresponds to %O_APPEND (see the documentation of the UNIX open() syscall)

parameter.name: G_IO_FLAG_NONBLOCK
parameter.parameter_description: turns on nonblocking mode, corresponds to %O_NONBLOCK/%O_NDELAY (see the documentation of the UNIX open() syscall)

parameter.name: G_IO_FLAG_IS_READABLE
parameter.parameter_description: indicates that the io channel is readable. This flag cannot be changed.

parameter.name: G_IO_FLAG_IS_WRITABLE
parameter.parameter_description: indicates that the io channel is writable. This flag cannot be changed.

parameter.name: G_IO_FLAG_IS_WRITEABLE
parameter.parameter_description: a misspelled version of @G_IO_FLAG_IS_WRITABLE that existed before the spelling was fixed in GLib 2.30. It is kept here for compatibility reasons. Deprecated since 2.30

parameter.name: G_IO_FLAG_IS_SEEKABLE
parameter.parameter_description: indicates that the io channel is seekable, i.e. that g_io_channel_seek_position() can be used on it. This flag cannot be changed.

parameter.name: G_IO_FLAG_MASK
parameter.parameter_description: the mask that specifies all the valid flags.

parameter.name: G_IO_FLAG_GET_MASK
parameter.parameter_description: the mask of the flags that are returned from g_io_channel_get_flags()

parameter.name: G_IO_FLAG_SET_MASK
parameter.parameter_description: the mask of the flags that the user can modify with g_io_channel_set_flags()

enum.name: GIOStatus
enum.description: Stati returned by most of the #GIOFuncs functions.

enum.name: GKeyFileError
enum.description: Error codes returned by key file parsing.

parameter.name: G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_UNKNOWN_ENCODING
parameter.parameter_description: the text being parsed was in an unknown encoding

parameter.name: G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND
parameter.parameter_description: a requested key was not found

parameter.name: G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_GROUP_NOT_FOUND
parameter.parameter_description: a requested group was not found

parameter.name: G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_INVALID_VALUE
parameter.parameter_description: a value could not be parsed

enum.name: GKeyFileFlags
enum.description: Flags which influence the parsing.

parameter.name: G_KEY_FILE_KEEP_COMMENTS
parameter.parameter_description: Use this flag if you plan to write the (possibly modified) contents of the key file back to a file; otherwise all comments will be lost when the key file is written back.

parameter.name: G_KEY_FILE_KEEP_TRANSLATIONS
parameter.parameter_description: Use this flag if you plan to write the (possibly modified) contents of the key file back to a file; otherwise only the translations for the current language will be written back.

enum.name: GLogLevelFlags
enum.description:
Flags specifying the level of log messages.
It is possible to change how GLib treats messages of the various levels using g_log_set_handler() and g_log_set_fatal_mask().

parameter.name: G_LOG_LEVEL_ERROR
parameter.parameter_description: log level for errors, see g_error(). This level is also used for messages produced by g_assert().

parameter.name: G_LOG_LEVEL_CRITICAL
parameter.parameter_description: log level for critical messages, see g_critical(). This level is also used for messages produced by g_return_if_fail() and g_return_val_if_fail().

parameter.name: G_LOG_LEVEL_WARNING
parameter.parameter_description: log level for warnings, see g_warning()

parameter.name: G_LOG_LEVEL_MESSAGE
parameter.parameter_description: log level for messages, see g_message()

parameter.name: G_LOG_LEVEL_INFO
parameter.parameter_description: log level for informational messages, see g_info()

parameter.name: G_LOG_LEVEL_DEBUG
parameter.parameter_description: log level for debug messages, see g_debug()

parameter.name: G_LOG_LEVEL_MASK
parameter.parameter_description: a mask including all log levels

enum.name: GMarkupCollectType
enum.description:
A mixed enumerated type and flags field. You must specify one type (string, strdup, boolean, tristate). Additionally, you may optionally bitwise OR the type with the flag %G_MARKUP_COLLECT_OPTIONAL.
It is likely that this enum will be extended in the future to support other types.

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_COLLECT_INVALID
parameter.parameter_description: used to terminate the list of attributes to collect

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_COLLECT_STRING
parameter.parameter_description: collect the string pointer directly from the attribute_values[] array. Expects a parameter of type (const char **). If %G_MARKUP_COLLECT_OPTIONAL is specified and the attribute isn't present then the pointer will be set to %NULL

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_COLLECT_STRDUP
parameter.parameter_description: as with %G_MARKUP_COLLECT_STRING, but expects a parameter of type (char **) and g_strdup()s the returned pointer. The pointer must be freed with g_free()

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_COLLECT_BOOLEAN
parameter.parameter_description: expects a parameter of type (gboolean *) and parses the attribute value as a boolean. Sets %FALSE if the attribute isn't present. Valid boolean values consist of (case-insensitive) "false", "f", "no", "n", "0" and "true", "t", "yes", "y", "1"

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_COLLECT_TRISTATE
parameter.parameter_description: as with %G_MARKUP_COLLECT_BOOLEAN, but in the case of a missing attribute a value is set that compares equal to neither %FALSE nor %TRUE G_MARKUP_COLLECT_OPTIONAL is implied

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_COLLECT_OPTIONAL
parameter.parameter_description: can be bitwise ORed with the other fields. If present, allows the attribute not to appear. A default value is set depending on what value type is used

enum.name: GMarkupError
enum.description: Error codes returned by markup parsing.

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_ERROR_BAD_UTF8
parameter.parameter_description: text being parsed was not valid UTF-8

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_ERROR_EMPTY
parameter.parameter_description: document contained nothing, or only whitespace

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_ERROR_UNKNOWN_ELEMENT
parameter.parameter_description: error should be set by #GMarkupParser functions; element wasn't known

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_ERROR_UNKNOWN_ATTRIBUTE
parameter.parameter_description: error should be set by #GMarkupParser functions; attribute wasn't known

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_ERROR_INVALID_CONTENT
parameter.parameter_description: error should be set by #GMarkupParser functions; content was invalid

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_ERROR_MISSING_ATTRIBUTE
parameter.parameter_description: error should be set by #GMarkupParser functions; a required attribute was missing

enum.name: GMarkupParseFlags
enum.description: Flags that affect the behaviour of the parser.

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_TREAT_CDATA_AS_TEXT
parameter.parameter_description: When this flag is set, CDATA marked sections are not passed literally to the @passthrough function of the parser. Instead, the content of the section (without the `<![CDATA[` and `]]>`) is passed to the @text function. This flag was added in GLib 2.12

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_PREFIX_ERROR_POSITION
parameter.parameter_description: Normally errors caught by GMarkup itself have line/column information prefixed to them to let the caller know the location of the error. When this flag is set the location information is also prefixed to errors generated by the #GMarkupParser implementation functions

parameter.name: G_MARKUP_IGNORE_QUALIFIED
parameter.parameter_description: Ignore (don't report) qualified attributes and tags, along with their contents. A qualified attribute or tag is one that contains ':' in its name (ie: is in another namespace). Since: 2.40.

enum.name: GModuleFlags
enum.description: Flags passed to g_module_open(). Note that these flags are not supported on all platforms.

parameter.name: G_MODULE_BIND_LAZY
parameter.parameter_description: specifies that symbols are only resolved when needed. The default action is to bind all symbols when the module is loaded.

parameter.name: G_MODULE_BIND_LOCAL
parameter.parameter_description: specifies that symbols in the module should not be added to the global name space. The default action on most platforms is to place symbols in the module in the global name space, which may cause conflicts with existing symbols.

enum.name: GNormalizeMode
enum.description: Defines how a Unicode string is transformed in a canonical form, standardizing such issues as whether a character with an accent is represented as a base character and combining accent or as a single precomposed character. Unicode strings should generally be normalized before comparing them.

parameter.name: G_NORMALIZE_DEFAULT
parameter.parameter_description: standardize differences that do not affect the text content, such as the above-mentioned accent representation

parameter.name: G_NORMALIZE_DEFAULT_COMPOSE
parameter.parameter_description: like %G_NORMALIZE_DEFAULT, but with composed forms rather than a maximally decomposed form

parameter.name: G_NORMALIZE_ALL
parameter.parameter_description: beyond %G_NORMALIZE_DEFAULT also standardize the "compatibility" characters in Unicode, such as SUPERSCRIPT THREE to the standard forms (in this case DIGIT THREE). Formatting information may be lost but for most text operations such characters should be considered the same

parameter.name: G_NORMALIZE_ALL_COMPOSE
parameter.parameter_description: like %G_NORMALIZE_ALL, but with composed forms rather than a maximally decomposed form

signal.name: GObject::notify
signal.description:
The notify signal is emitted on an object when one of its properties has been changed. Note that getting this signal doesn't guarantee that the value of the property has actually changed, it may also be emitted when the setter for the property is called to reinstate the previous value.
This signal is typically used to obtain change notification for a single property, by specifying the property name as a detail in the g_signal_connect() call, like this: |[<!-- language="C" --> g_signal_connect (text_view->buffer, "notify::paste-target-list", G_CALLBACK (gtk_text_view_target_list_notify), text_view) ]| It is important to note that you must use [canonical][canonical-parameter-name] parameter names as detail strings for the notify signal.

parameter.name: gobject
parameter.parameter_description: the object which received the signal.

parameter.name: pspec
parameter.parameter_description: the #GParamSpec of the property which changed.

enum.name: GOnceStatus
enum.description:
The possible statuses of a one-time initialization function controlled by a #GOnce struct.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: G_ONCE_STATUS_NOTCALLED
parameter.parameter_description: the function has not been called yet.

parameter.name: G_ONCE_STATUS_PROGRESS
parameter.parameter_description: the function call is currently in progress.

enum.name: GOptionArg
enum.description: The #GOptionArg enum values determine which type of extra argument the options expect to find. If an option expects an extra argument, it can be specified in several ways; with a short option: `-x arg`, with a long option: `--name arg` or combined in a single argument: `--name=arg`.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ARG_NONE
parameter.parameter_description: No extra argument. This is useful for simple flags.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ARG_STRING
parameter.parameter_description: The option takes a string argument.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ARG_INT
parameter.parameter_description: The option takes an integer argument.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ARG_CALLBACK
parameter.parameter_description: The option provides a callback to parse the extra argument.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ARG_FILENAME
parameter.parameter_description: The option takes a filename as argument.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ARG_STRING_ARRAY
parameter.parameter_description: The option takes a string argument, multiple uses of the option are collected into an array of strings.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ARG_FILENAME_ARRAY
parameter.parameter_description: The option takes a filename as argument, multiple uses of the option are collected into an array of strings.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ARG_DOUBLE
parameter.parameter_description: The option takes a double argument. The argument can be formatted either for the user's locale or for the "C" locale. Since 2.12

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ARG_INT64
parameter.parameter_description: The option takes a 64-bit integer. Like %G_OPTION_ARG_INT but for larger numbers. The number can be in decimal base, or in hexadecimal (when prefixed with `0x`, for example, `0xffffffff`). Since 2.12

enum.name: GOptionError
enum.description: Error codes returned by option parsing.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_ERROR_UNKNOWN_OPTION
parameter.parameter_description: An option was not known to the parser. This error will only be reported, if the parser hasn't been instructed to ignore unknown options, see g_option_context_set_ignore_unknown_options().

enum.name: GOptionFlags
enum.description: Flags which modify individual options.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_FLAG_HIDDEN
parameter.parameter_description: The option doesn't appear in `--help` output.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_FLAG_IN_MAIN
parameter.parameter_description: The option appears in the main section of the `--help` output, even if it is defined in a group.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_FLAG_REVERSE
parameter.parameter_description: For options of the %G_OPTION_ARG_NONE kind, this flag indicates that the sense of the option is reversed.

parameter.name: G_OPTION_FLAG_NO_ARG
parameter.parameter_description: For options of the %G_OPTION_ARG_CALLBACK kind, this flag indicates that the callback does not take any argument (like a %G_OPTION_ARG_NONE option). Since 2.8

parameter.name: G_OPTION_FLAG_FILENAME
parameter.parameter_description: For options of the %G_OPTION_ARG_CALLBACK kind, this flag indicates that the argument should be passed to the callback in the GLib filename encoding rather than UTF-8. Since 2.8

parameter.name: G_OPTION_FLAG_OPTIONAL_ARG
parameter.parameter_description: For options of the %G_OPTION_ARG_CALLBACK kind, this flag indicates that the argument supply is optional. If no argument is given then data of %GOptionParseFunc will be set to NULL. Since 2.8

parameter.name: G_OPTION_FLAG_NOALIAS
parameter.parameter_description: This flag turns off the automatic conflict resolution which prefixes long option names with `groupname-` if there is a conflict. This option should only be used in situations where aliasing is necessary to model some legacy commandline interface. It is not safe to use this option, unless all option groups are under your direct control. Since 2.8.

enum.name: GParamFlags
enum.description: Through the #GParamFlags flag values, certain aspects of parameters can be configured. See also #G_PARAM_READWRITE and #G_PARAM_STATIC_STRINGS.

parameter.name: G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT
parameter.parameter_description: the parameter will be set upon object construction

parameter.name: G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT_ONLY
parameter.parameter_description: the parameter will only be set upon object construction

parameter.name: G_PARAM_LAX_VALIDATION
parameter.parameter_description: upon parameter conversion (see g_param_value_convert()) strict validation is not required

parameter.name: G_PARAM_STATIC_NAME
parameter.parameter_description: the string used as name when constructing the parameter is guaranteed to remain valid and unmodified for the lifetime of the parameter. Since 2.8

parameter.name: G_PARAM_STATIC_NICK
parameter.parameter_description: the string used as nick when constructing the parameter is guaranteed to remain valid and unmmodified for the lifetime of the parameter. Since 2.8

parameter.name: G_PARAM_STATIC_BLURB
parameter.parameter_description: the string used as blurb when constructing the parameter is guaranteed to remain valid and unmodified for the lifetime of the parameter. Since 2.8

parameter.name: G_PARAM_EXPLICIT_NOTIFY
parameter.parameter_description: calls to g_object_set_property() for this property will not automatically result in a "notify" signal being emitted: the implementation must call g_object_notify() themselves in case the property actually changes. Since: 2.42.

parameter.name: G_PARAM_DEPRECATED
parameter.parameter_description: the parameter is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. A warning will be generated if it is used while running with G_ENABLE_DIAGNOSTIC=1. Since 2.26

enum.name: GRegexCompileFlags
enum.description:
Flags specifying compile-time options.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: G_REGEX_CASELESS
parameter.parameter_description: Letters in the pattern match both upper- and lowercase letters. This option can be changed within a pattern by a "(?i)" option setting.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MULTILINE
parameter.parameter_description: By default, GRegex treats the strings as consisting of a single line of characters (even if it actually contains newlines). The "start of line" metacharacter ("^") matches only at the start of the string, while the "end of line" metacharacter ("$") matches only at the end of the string, or before a terminating newline (unless #G_REGEX_DOLLAR_ENDONLY is set). When #G_REGEX_MULTILINE is set, the "start of line" and "end of line" constructs match immediately following or immediately before any newline in the string, respectively, as well as at the very start and end. This can be changed within a pattern by a "(?m)" option setting.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_DOTALL
parameter.parameter_description: A dot metacharater (".") in the pattern matches all characters, including newlines. Without it, newlines are excluded. This option can be changed within a pattern by a ("?s") option setting.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_EXTENDED
parameter.parameter_description: Whitespace data characters in the pattern are totally ignored except when escaped or inside a character class. Whitespace does not include the VT character (code 11). In addition, characters between an unescaped "#" outside a character class and the next newline character, inclusive, are also ignored. This can be changed within a pattern by a "(?x)" option setting.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ANCHORED
parameter.parameter_description: The pattern is forced to be "anchored", that is, it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being searched. This effect can also be achieved by appropriate constructs in the pattern itself such as the "^" metacharater.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_DOLLAR_ENDONLY
parameter.parameter_description: A dollar metacharacter ("$") in the pattern matches only at the end of the string. Without this option, a dollar also matches immediately before the final character if it is a newline (but not before any other newlines). This option is ignored if #G_REGEX_MULTILINE is set.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_UNGREEDY
parameter.parameter_description: Inverts the "greediness" of the quantifiers so that they are not greedy by default, but become greedy if followed by "?". It can also be set by a "(?U)" option setting within the pattern.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_RAW
parameter.parameter_description: Usually strings must be valid UTF-8 strings, using this flag they are considered as a raw sequence of bytes.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_NO_AUTO_CAPTURE
parameter.parameter_description: Disables the use of numbered capturing parentheses in the pattern. Any opening parenthesis that is not followed by "?" behaves as if it were followed by "?:" but named parentheses can still be used for capturing (and they acquire numbers in the usual way).

parameter.name: G_REGEX_OPTIMIZE
parameter.parameter_description: Optimize the regular expression. If the pattern will be used many times, then it may be worth the effort to optimize it to improve the speed of matches.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_FIRSTLINE
parameter.parameter_description: Limits an unanchored pattern to match before (or at) the first newline. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_DUPNAMES
parameter.parameter_description: Names used to identify capturing subpatterns need not be unique. This can be helpful for certain types of pattern when it is known that only one instance of the named subpattern can ever be matched.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_NEWLINE_CR
parameter.parameter_description: Usually any newline character or character sequence is recognized. If this option is set, the only recognized newline character is '\r'.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_NEWLINE_LF
parameter.parameter_description: Usually any newline character or character sequence is recognized. If this option is set, the only recognized newline character is '\n'.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_NEWLINE_CRLF
parameter.parameter_description: Usually any newline character or character sequence is recognized. If this option is set, the only recognized newline character sequence is '\r\n'.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_NEWLINE_ANYCRLF
parameter.parameter_description: Usually any newline character or character sequence is recognized. If this option is set, the only recognized newline character sequences are '\r', '\n', and '\r\n'. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_BSR_ANYCRLF
parameter.parameter_description: Usually any newline character or character sequence is recognised. If this option is set, then "\R" only recognizes the newline characters '\r', '\n' and '\r\n'. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_JAVASCRIPT_COMPAT
parameter.parameter_description: Changes behaviour so that it is compatible with JavaScript rather than PCRE. Since: 2.34

enum.name: GRegexError
enum.description:
Error codes returned by regular expressions functions.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_COMPILE
parameter.parameter_description: Compilation of the regular expression failed.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_OPTIMIZE
parameter.parameter_description: Optimization of the regular expression failed.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_REPLACE
parameter.parameter_description: Replacement failed due to an ill-formed replacement string.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_INTERNAL
parameter.parameter_description: Internal error of the regular expression engine. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_QUANTIFIERS_OUT_OF_ORDER
parameter.parameter_description: Numbers out of order in "{}" quantifier. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_QUANTIFIER_TOO_BIG
parameter.parameter_description: Number too big in "{}" quantifier. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_UNTERMINATED_CHARACTER_CLASS
parameter.parameter_description: Missing terminating "]" for character class. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_INVALID_ESCAPE_IN_CHARACTER_CLASS
parameter.parameter_description: Invalid escape sequence in character class. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_RANGE_OUT_OF_ORDER
parameter.parameter_description: Range out of order in character class. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_POSIX_NAMED_CLASS_OUTSIDE_CLASS
parameter.parameter_description: POSIX named classes are supported only within a class. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_UNMATCHED_PARENTHESIS
parameter.parameter_description: Missing terminating ")" or ")" without opening "(". Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_VARIABLE_LENGTH_LOOKBEHIND
parameter.parameter_description: Lookbehind assertion is not fixed length. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_MALFORMED_CONDITION
parameter.parameter_description: Malformed number or name after "(?(". Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_TOO_MANY_CONDITIONAL_BRANCHES
parameter.parameter_description: Conditional group contains more than two branches. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_POSIX_COLLATING_ELEMENTS_NOT_SUPPORTED
parameter.parameter_description: POSIX collating elements are not supported. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_HEX_CODE_TOO_LARGE
parameter.parameter_description: Character value in "\\x{...}" sequence is too large. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_SINGLE_BYTE_MATCH_IN_LOOKBEHIND
parameter.parameter_description: \\C not allowed in lookbehind assertion. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_INFINITE_LOOP
parameter.parameter_description: Recursive call could loop indefinitely. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_MISSING_SUBPATTERN_NAME_TERMINATOR
parameter.parameter_description: Missing terminator in subpattern name. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_DUPLICATE_SUBPATTERN_NAME
parameter.parameter_description: Two named subpatterns have the same name. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROPERTY
parameter.parameter_description: Unknown property name after "\\P" or "\\p". Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_SUBPATTERN_NAME_TOO_LONG
parameter.parameter_description: Subpattern name is too long (maximum 32 characters). Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_INVALID_OCTAL_VALUE
parameter.parameter_description: Octal value is greater than "\\377". Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_TOO_MANY_BRANCHES_IN_DEFINE
parameter.parameter_description: "DEFINE" group contains more than one branch. Since 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_DEFINE_REPETION
parameter.parameter_description: Repeating a "DEFINE" group is not allowed. This error is never raised. Since: 2.16 Deprecated: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_MISSING_BACK_REFERENCE
parameter.parameter_description: "\\g" is not followed by a braced, angle-bracketed, or quoted name or number, or by a plain number. Since: 2.16

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_INVALID_RELATIVE_REFERENCE
parameter.parameter_description: relative reference must not be zero. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_BACKTRACKING_CONTROL_VERB_ARGUMENT_FORBIDDEN
parameter.parameter_description: the backtracing control verb used does not allow an argument. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_NUMBER_TOO_BIG
parameter.parameter_description: number is too big in escape sequence. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_INVALID_DATA_CHARACTER
parameter.parameter_description: In JavaScript compatibility mode, "[" is an invalid data character. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_EXTRA_SUBPATTERN_NAME
parameter.parameter_description: different names for subpatterns of the same number are not allowed. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_BACKTRACKING_CONTROL_VERB_ARGUMENT_REQUIRED
parameter.parameter_description: the backtracing control verb requires an argument. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_INVALID_CONTROL_CHAR
parameter.parameter_description: "\\c" must be followed by an ASCII character. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_MISSING_NAME
parameter.parameter_description: "\\k" is not followed by a braced, angle-bracketed, or quoted name. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED_IN_CLASS
parameter.parameter_description: "\\N" is not supported in a class. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_NAME_TOO_LONG
parameter.parameter_description: the name is too long in "(*MARK)", "(*PRUNE)", "(*SKIP)", or "(*THEN)". Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_ERROR_CHARACTER_VALUE_TOO_LARGE
parameter.parameter_description: the character value in the \\u sequence is too large. Since: 2.34

enum.name: GRegexMatchFlags
enum.description:
Flags specifying match-time options.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_ANCHORED
parameter.parameter_description: The pattern is forced to be "anchored", that is, it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being searched. This effect can also be achieved by appropriate constructs in the pattern itself such as the "^" metacharater.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTBOL
parameter.parameter_description: Specifies that first character of the string is not the beginning of a line, so the circumflex metacharacter should not match before it. Setting this without #G_REGEX_MULTILINE (at compile time) causes circumflex never to match. This option affects only the behaviour of the circumflex metacharacter, it does not affect "\A".

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTEOL
parameter.parameter_description: Specifies that the end of the subject string is not the end of a line, so the dollar metacharacter should not match it nor (except in multiline mode) a newline immediately before it. Setting this without #G_REGEX_MULTILINE (at compile time) causes dollar never to match. This option affects only the behaviour of the dollar metacharacter, it does not affect "\Z" or "\z".

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTEMPTY
parameter.parameter_description: An empty string is not considered to be a valid match if this option is set. If there are alternatives in the pattern, they are tried. If all the alternatives match the empty string, the entire match fails. For example, if the pattern "a?b?" is applied to a string not beginning with "a" or "b", it matches the empty string at the start of the string. With this flag set, this match is not valid, so GRegex searches further into the string for occurrences of "a" or "b".

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_PARTIAL
parameter.parameter_description: Turns on the partial matching feature, for more documentation on partial matching see g_match_info_is_partial_match().

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_NEWLINE_CR
parameter.parameter_description: Overrides the newline definition set when creating a new #GRegex, setting the '\r' character as line terminator.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_NEWLINE_LF
parameter.parameter_description: Overrides the newline definition set when creating a new #GRegex, setting the '\n' character as line terminator.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_NEWLINE_CRLF
parameter.parameter_description: Overrides the newline definition set when creating a new #GRegex, setting the '\r\n' characters sequence as line terminator.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_NEWLINE_ANY
parameter.parameter_description: Overrides the newline definition set when creating a new #GRegex, any Unicode newline sequence is recognised as a newline. These are '\r', '\n' and '\rn', and the single characters U+000B LINE TABULATION, U+000C FORM FEED (FF), U+0085 NEXT LINE (NEL), U+2028 LINE SEPARATOR and U+2029 PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR.

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_NEWLINE_ANYCRLF
parameter.parameter_description: Overrides the newline definition set when creating a new #GRegex; any '\r', '\n', or '\r\n' character sequence is recognized as a newline. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_BSR_ANYCRLF
parameter.parameter_description: Overrides the newline definition for "\R" set when creating a new #GRegex; only '\r', '\n', or '\r\n' character sequences are recognized as a newline by "\R". Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_BSR_ANY
parameter.parameter_description: Overrides the newline definition for "\R" set when creating a new #GRegex; any Unicode newline character or character sequence are recognized as a newline by "\R". These are '\r', '\n' and '\rn', and the single characters U+000B LINE TABULATION, U+000C FORM FEED (FF), U+0085 NEXT LINE (NEL), U+2028 LINE SEPARATOR and U+2029 PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_PARTIAL_HARD
parameter.parameter_description: Turns on the partial matching feature. In contrast to to #G_REGEX_MATCH_PARTIAL_SOFT, this stops matching as soon as a partial match is found, without continuing to search for a possible complete match. See g_match_info_is_partial_match() for more information. Since: 2.34

parameter.name: G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTEMPTY_ATSTART
parameter.parameter_description: Like #G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTEMPTY, but only applied to the start of the matched string. For anchored patterns this can only happen for pattern containing "\K". Since: 2.34

enum.name: GSeekType
enum.description: An enumeration specifying the base position for a g_io_channel_seek_position() operation.

parameter.name: G_SEEK_CUR
parameter.parameter_description: the current position in the file.

enum.name: GShellError
enum.description: Error codes returned by shell functions.

parameter.name: G_SHELL_ERROR_EMPTY_STRING
parameter.parameter_description: String to be parsed was empty.

enum.name: GSignalFlags
enum.description: The signal flags are used to specify a signal's behaviour, the overall signal description outlines how especially the RUN flags control the stages of a signal emission.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_RUN_FIRST
parameter.parameter_description: Invoke the object method handler in the first emission stage.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_RUN_LAST
parameter.parameter_description: Invoke the object method handler in the third emission stage.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_RUN_CLEANUP
parameter.parameter_description: Invoke the object method handler in the last emission stage.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_NO_RECURSE
parameter.parameter_description: Signals being emitted for an object while currently being in emission for this very object will not be emitted recursively, but instead cause the first emission to be restarted.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_DETAILED
parameter.parameter_description: This signal supports "::detail" appendices to the signal name upon handler connections and emissions.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_ACTION
parameter.parameter_description: Action signals are signals that may freely be emitted on alive objects from user code via g_signal_emit() and friends, without the need of being embedded into extra code that performs pre or post emission adjustments on the object. They can also be thought of as object methods which can be called generically by third-party code.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_NO_HOOKS
parameter.parameter_description: No emissions hooks are supported for this signal.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_MUST_COLLECT
parameter.parameter_description: Varargs signal emission will always collect the arguments, even if there are no signal handlers connected. Since 2.30.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_DEPRECATED
parameter.parameter_description: The signal is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. A warning will be generated if it is connected while running with G_ENABLE_DIAGNOSTIC=1. Since 2.32.

enum.name: GSignalMatchType
enum.description: The match types specify what g_signal_handlers_block_matched(), g_signal_handlers_unblock_matched() and g_signal_handlers_disconnect_matched() match signals by.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_MATCH_ID
parameter.parameter_description: The signal id must be equal.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_MATCH_CLOSURE
parameter.parameter_description: The closure must be the same.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_MATCH_FUNC
parameter.parameter_description: The C closure callback must be the same.

parameter.name: G_SIGNAL_MATCH_DATA
parameter.parameter_description: The closure data must be the same.

enum.name: GSpawnError
enum.description: Error codes returned by spawning processes.

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_ERROR_FORK
parameter.parameter_description: Fork failed due to lack of memory.

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_ERROR_READ
parameter.parameter_description: Read or select on pipes failed.

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_ERROR_FAILED
parameter.parameter_description: Some other fatal failure, `error->message` should explain.

enum.name: GSpawnFlags
enum.description: Flags passed to g_spawn_sync(), g_spawn_async() and g_spawn_async_with_pipes().

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_LEAVE_DESCRIPTORS_OPEN
parameter.parameter_description: the parent's open file descriptors will be inherited by the child; otherwise all descriptors except stdin, stdout and stderr will be closed before calling exec() in the child.

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_DO_NOT_REAP_CHILD
G_SPAWN_SEARCH_PATH
parameter.parameter_description: `argv[0]` need not be an absolute path, it will be looked for in the user's `PATH`.

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_STDOUT_TO_DEV_NULL
parameter.parameter_description: the child's standard output will be discarded, instead of going to the same location as the parent's standard output.

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_STDERR_TO_DEV_NULL
parameter.parameter_description: the child's standard error will be discarded.

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_CHILD_INHERITS_STDIN
parameter.parameter_description: the child will inherit the parent's standard input (by default, the child's standard input is attached to `/dev/null`).

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_FILE_AND_ARGV_ZERO
parameter.parameter_description: the first element of `argv` is the file to execute, while the remaining elements are the actual argument vector to pass to the file. Normally g_spawn_async_with_pipes() uses `argv[0]` as the file to execute, and passes all of `argv` to the child.

parameter.name: G_SPAWN_SEARCH_PATH_FROM_ENVP
G_SPAWN_CLOEXEC_PIPES
parameter.parameter_description: create all pipes with the `O_CLOEXEC` flag set. Since: 2.40

enum.name: GTestFileType
enum.description:
The type of file to return the filename for, when used with g_test_build_filename().
These two options correspond rather directly to the 'dist' and 'built' terminology that automake uses and are explicitly used to distinguish between the 'srcdir' and 'builddir' being separate. All files in your project should either be dist (in the `DIST_EXTRA` or `dist_schema_DATA` sense, in which case they will always be in the srcdir) or built (in the `BUILT_SOURCES` sense, in which case they will always be in the builddir).
Note: as a general rule of automake, files that are generated only as part of the build-from-git process (but then are distributed with the tarball) always go in srcdir (even if doing a srcdir != builddir build from git) and are considered as distributed files.
Since: 2.38

parameter.name: G_TEST_DIST
parameter.parameter_description: a file that was included in the distribution tarball

parameter.name: G_TEST_BUILT
parameter.parameter_description: a file that was built on the compiling machine

enum.name: GTestSubprocessFlags
enum.description:
Flags to pass to g_test_trap_subprocess() to control input and output.
Note that in contrast with g_test_trap_fork(), the default is to not show stdout and stderr.

parameter.name: G_TEST_SUBPROCESS_INHERIT_STDIN
parameter.parameter_description: If this flag is given, the child process will inherit the parent's stdin. Otherwise, the child's stdin is redirected to `/dev/null`.

parameter.name: G_TEST_SUBPROCESS_INHERIT_STDOUT
parameter.parameter_description: If this flag is given, the child process will inherit the parent's stdout. Otherwise, the child's stdout will not be visible, but it will be captured to allow later tests with g_test_trap_assert_stdout().

parameter.name: G_TEST_SUBPROCESS_INHERIT_STDERR
parameter.parameter_description: If this flag is given, the child process will inherit the parent's stderr. Otherwise, the child's stderr will not be visible, but it will be captured to allow later tests with g_test_trap_assert_stderr().

enum.name: GTestTrapFlags
enum.description:
Test traps are guards around forked tests. These flags determine what traps to set.
Deprecated: #GTestTrapFlags is used only with g_test_trap_fork(), which is deprecated. g_test_trap_subprocess() uses #GTestTrapSubprocessFlags.

parameter.name: G_TEST_TRAP_SILENCE_STDOUT
parameter.parameter_description: Redirect stdout of the test child to `/dev/null` so it cannot be observed on the console during test runs. The actual output is still captured though to allow later tests with g_test_trap_assert_stdout().

parameter.name: G_TEST_TRAP_SILENCE_STDERR
parameter.parameter_description: Redirect stderr of the test child to `/dev/null` so it cannot be observed on the console during test runs. The actual output is still captured though to allow later tests with g_test_trap_assert_stderr().

parameter.name: G_TEST_TRAP_INHERIT_STDIN
parameter.parameter_description: If this flag is given, stdin of the child process is shared with stdin of its parent process. It is redirected to `/dev/null` otherwise.

enum.name: GThreadError
enum.description: Possible errors of thread related functions.

parameter.name: G_THREAD_ERROR_AGAIN
parameter.parameter_description: a thread couldn't be created due to resource shortage. Try again later.

enum.name: GThreadPriority
enum.description:
Thread priorities.
Deprecated:2.32: Thread priorities no longer have any effect.

enum.name: GTimeType
enum.description:
Disambiguates a given time in two ways.
First, specifies if the given time is in universal or local time.
Second, if the time is in local time, specifies if it is local standard time or local daylight time. This is important for the case where the same local time occurs twice (during daylight savings time transitions, for example).

parameter.name: G_TIME_TYPE_STANDARD
parameter.parameter_description: the time is in local standard time

parameter.name: G_TIME_TYPE_DAYLIGHT
parameter.parameter_description: the time is in local daylight time

enum.name: GTokenType
enum.description: The possible types of token returned from each g_scanner_get_next_token() call.

enum.name: GTraverseFlags
enum.description: Specifies which nodes are visited during several of the tree functions, including g_node_traverse() and g_node_find().

parameter.name: G_TRAVERSE_LEAVES
parameter.parameter_description: only leaf nodes should be visited. This name has been introduced in 2.6, for older version use %G_TRAVERSE_LEAFS.

parameter.name: G_TRAVERSE_NON_LEAVES
parameter.parameter_description: only non-leaf nodes should be visited. This name has been introduced in 2.6, for older version use %G_TRAVERSE_NON_LEAFS.

parameter.name: G_TRAVERSE_MASK
parameter.parameter_description: a mask of all traverse flags.

enum.name: GTraverseType
enum.description: Specifies the type of traveral performed by g_tree_traverse(), g_node_traverse() and g_node_find(). The different orders are illustrated here: - In order: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I ![](Sorted_binary_tree_inorder.svg) - Pre order: F, B, A, D, C, E, G, I, H ![](Sorted_binary_tree_preorder.svg) - Post order: A, C, E, D, B, H, I, G, F ![](Sorted_binary_tree_postorder.svg) - Level order: F, B, G, A, D, I, C, E, H ![](Sorted_binary_tree_breadth-first_traversal.svg)

parameter.name: G_IN_ORDER
parameter.parameter_description: vists a node's left child first, then the node itself, then its right child. This is the one to use if you want the output sorted according to the compare function.

parameter.name: G_PRE_ORDER
parameter.parameter_description: visits a node, then its children.

parameter.name: G_POST_ORDER
parameter.parameter_description: visits the node's children, then the node itself.

parameter.name: G_LEVEL_ORDER
parameter.parameter_description: is not implemented for [balanced binary trees][glib-Balanced-Binary-Trees]. For [n-ary trees][glib-N-ary-Trees], it vists the root node first, then its children, then its grandchildren, and so on. Note that this is less efficient than the other orders.

enum.name: GTypeDebugFlags
enum.description:
These flags used to be passed to g_type_init_with_debug_flags() which is now deprecated.
If you need to enable debugging features, use the GOBJECT_DEBUG environment variable.
Deprecated: 2.36: g_type_init() is now done automatically

enum.name: GTypeFlags
enum.description: Bit masks used to check or determine characteristics of a type.

parameter.name: G_TYPE_FLAG_ABSTRACT
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates an abstract type. No instances can be created for an abstract type

parameter.name: G_TYPE_FLAG_VALUE_ABSTRACT
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates an abstract value type, i.e. a type that introduces a value table, but can't be used for g_value_init()

enum.name: GTypeFundamentalFlags
enum.description: Bit masks used to check or determine specific characteristics of a fundamental type.

parameter.name: G_TYPE_FLAG_DEEP_DERIVABLE
parameter.parameter_description: Indicates a deep derivable type (implies derivable)

enum.name: GUnicodeBreakType
enum.description:
These are the possible line break classifications.
Since new unicode versions may add new types here, applications should be ready to handle unknown values. They may be regarded as %G_UNICODE_BREAK_UNKNOWN.
See <ulink url="http://www.unicode.org/unicode/reports/tr14/">http://www.unicode.org/unicode/reports/tr14/</ulink>.

enum.name: GUnicodeScript
enum.description:
The #GUnicodeScript enumeration identifies different writing systems. The values correspond to the names as defined in the Unicode standard. The enumeration has been added in GLib 2.14, and is interchangeable with #PangoScript.
Note that new types may be added in the future. Applications should be ready to handle unknown values. See <ulink url="http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr24/">Unicode Standard Annex #24: Script names</ulink>.

parameter.name: G_UNICODE_SCRIPT_INVALID_CODE
parameter.parameter_description: a value never returned from g_unichar_get_script()

parameter.name: G_UNICODE_SCRIPT_COMMON
parameter.parameter_description: a character used by multiple different scripts

parameter.name: G_UNICODE_SCRIPT_INHERITED
parameter.parameter_description: a mark glyph that takes its script from the i base glyph to which it is attached

enum.name: GUnicodeType
enum.description: These are the possible character classifications from the Unicode specification. See <ulink url="http://www.unicode.org/Public/UNIDATA/UnicodeData.html">http://www.unicode.org/Public/UNIDATA/UnicodeData.html</ulink>.

enum.name: GUserDirectory
enum.description:
These are logical ids for special directories which are defined depending on the platform used. You should use g_get_user_special_dir() to retrieve the full path associated to the logical id.
The #GUserDirectory enumeration can be extended at later date. Not every platform has a directory for every logical id in this enumeration.
Since: 2.14

enum.name: GVariantClass
enum.description:
The range of possible top-level types of #GVariant instances.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_INT16
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is a signed 16 bit integer.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_UINT16
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is an unsigned 16 bit integer.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_INT32
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is a signed 32 bit integer.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_UINT32
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is an unsigned 32 bit integer.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_INT64
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is a signed 64 bit integer.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_UINT64
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is an unsigned 64 bit integer.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_HANDLE
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is a file handle index.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_DOUBLE
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is a double precision floating point value.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_OBJECT_PATH
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is a D-Bus object path string.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_CLASS_SIGNATURE
parameter.parameter_description: The #GVariant is a D-Bus signature string.

enum.name: GVariantParseError
enum.description: Error codes returned by parsing text-format GVariants.

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_PARSE_ERROR_BASIC_TYPE_EXPECTED
parameter.parameter_description: a non-basic #GVariantType was given where a basic type was expected

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_PARSE_ERROR_DEFINITE_TYPE_EXPECTED
parameter.parameter_description: an indefinite #GVariantType was given where a definite type was expected

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_PARSE_ERROR_INVALID_CHARACTER
parameter.parameter_description: invalid character in number or unicode escape

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_PARSE_ERROR_NO_COMMON_TYPE
parameter.parameter_description: could not find a common type for array entries

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_PARSE_ERROR_NUMBER_OUT_OF_RANGE
parameter.parameter_description: the numerical value is out of range of the given type

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_PARSE_ERROR_NUMBER_TOO_BIG
parameter.parameter_description: the numerical value is out of range for any type

parameter.name: G_VARIANT_PARSE_ERROR_TYPE_ERROR
parameter.parameter_description: cannot parse as variant of the specified type

function.name: g_access
function.description:
A wrapper for the POSIX access() function. This function is used to test a pathname for one or several of read, write or execute permissions, or just existence.
On Windows, the file protection mechanism is not at all POSIX-like, and the underlying function in the C library only checks the FAT-style READONLY attribute, and does not look at the ACL of a file at all. This function is this in practise almost useless on Windows. Software that needs to handle file permissions on Windows more exactly should use the Win32 API.
See your C library manual for more details about access().
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding (UTF-8 on Windows)

function.return: zero if the pathname refers to an existing file system object that has all the tested permissions, or -1 otherwise or on error.

function.name: g_alloca
function.description:
Allocates @size bytes on the stack; these bytes will be freed when the current stack frame is cleaned up. This macro essentially just wraps the alloca() function present on most UNIX variants. Thus it provides the same advantages and pitfalls as alloca():
- alloca() is very fast, as on most systems it's implemented by just adjusting the stack pointer register.
- It doesn't cause any memory fragmentation, within its scope, separate alloca() blocks just build up and are released together at function end.
- Allocation sizes have to fit into the current stack frame. For instance in a threaded environment on Linux, the per-thread stack size is limited to 2 Megabytes, so be sparse with alloca() uses.
- Allocation failure due to insufficient stack space is not indicated with a %NULL return like e.g. with malloc(). Instead, most systems probably handle it the same way as out of stack space situations from infinite function recursion, i.e. with a segmentation fault.
- Special care has to be taken when mixing alloca() with GNU C variable sized arrays. Stack space allocated with alloca() in the same scope as a variable sized array will be freed together with the variable sized array upon exit of that scope, and not upon exit of the enclosing function scope.
function.return: space for @size bytes, allocated on the stack

function.name: g_array_append_val
function.description:
Adds the value on to the end of the array. The array will grow in size automatically if necessary.
g_array_append_val() is a macro which uses a reference to the value parameter @v. This means that you cannot use it with literal values such as "27". You must use variables.

parameter.name: v
parameter.parameter_description: the value to append to the #GArray

function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_append_vals
function.description: Adds @len elements onto the end of the array.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the elements to append to the end of the array

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: the number of elements to append

function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_free
function.description:
Frees the memory allocated for the #GArray. If @free_segment is %TRUE it frees the memory block holding the elements as well and also each element if @array has a @element_free_func set. Pass %FALSE if you want to free the #GArray wrapper but preserve the underlying array for use elsewhere. If the reference count of @array is greater than one, the #GArray wrapper is preserved but the size of @array will be set to zero.
If array elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, they should be freed separately.

parameter.name: free_segment
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE the actual element data is freed as well

function.return: the element data if @free_segment is %FALSE, otherwise %NULL. The element data should be freed using g_free().

function.name: g_array_get_element_size
function.description:
Gets the size of the elements in @array.
Since: 2.22
function.return: Size of each element, in bytes

function.name: g_array_index

parameter.name: i
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the element to return

function.return: the element of the #GArray at the index given by @i

function.name: g_array_insert_val
function.description:
Inserts an element into an array at the given index.
g_array_insert_val() is a macro which uses a reference to the value parameter @v. This means that you cannot use it with literal values such as "27". You must use variables.

parameter.name: i
parameter.parameter_description: the index to place the element at

parameter.name: v
parameter.parameter_description: the value to insert into the array

function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_insert_vals
function.description: Inserts @len elements into a #GArray at the given index.

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index to place the elements at

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the elements to insert

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: the number of elements to insert

function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_new
function.description: Creates a new #GArray with a reference count of 1.

parameter.name: zero_terminated
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the array should have an extra element at the end which is set to 0

parameter.name: clear_
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if #GArray elements should be automatically cleared to 0 when they are allocated

parameter.name: element_size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of each element in bytes

function.return: the new #GArray

function.name: g_array_prepend_val
function.description:
Adds the value on to the start of the array. The array will grow in size automatically if necessary.
This operation is slower than g_array_append_val() since the existing elements in the array have to be moved to make space for the new element.
g_array_prepend_val() is a macro which uses a reference to the value parameter @v. This means that you cannot use it with literal values such as "27". You must use variables.

parameter.name: v
parameter.parameter_description: the value to prepend to the #GArray

function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_prepend_vals
function.description:
Adds @len elements onto the start of the array.
This operation is slower than g_array_append_vals() since the existing elements in the array have to be moved to make space for the new elements.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the elements to prepend to the start of the array

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: the number of elements to prepend

function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_ref
function.description:
Atomically increments the reference count of @array by one. This function is MT-safe and may be called from any thread.
Since: 2.22
function.return: The passed in #GArray

function.name: g_array_remove_index
function.description: Removes the element at the given index from a #GArray. The following elements are moved down one place.

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the element to remove

function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_remove_index_fast
function.description: Removes the element at the given index from a #GArray. The last element in the array is used to fill in the space, so this function does not preserve the order of the #GArray. But it is faster than g_array_remove_index().

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the element to remove

function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_remove_range
function.description:
Removes the given number of elements starting at the given index from a #GArray. The following elements are moved to close the gap.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the first element to remove

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the number of elements to remove

function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_set_clear_func
function.description:
Sets a function to clear an element of @array.
The @clear_func will be called when an element in the array data segment is removed and when the array is freed and data segment is deallocated as well.
Note that in contrast with other uses of #GDestroyNotify functions, @clear_func is expected to clear the contents of the array element it is given, but not free the element itself.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: clear_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to clear an element of @array

function.name: g_array_set_size
function.description: Sets the size of the array, expanding it if necessary. If the array was created with @clear_ set to %TRUE, the new elements are set to 0.
function.return: the #GArray

function.name: g_array_sized_new
function.description: Creates a new #GArray with @reserved_size elements preallocated and a reference count of 1. This avoids frequent reallocation, if you are going to add many elements to the array. Note however that the size of the array is still 0.

parameter.name: zero_terminated
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the array should have an extra element at the end with all bits cleared

parameter.name: clear_
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if all bits in the array should be cleared to 0 on allocation

parameter.name: element_size
parameter.parameter_description: size of each element in the array

function.return: the new #GArray

function.name: g_array_sort
function.description:
Sorts a #GArray using @compare_func which should be a qsort()-style comparison function (returns less than zero for first arg is less than second arg, zero for equal, greater zero if first arg is greater than second arg).
This is guaranteed to be a stable sort since version 2.32.

function.name: g_array_sort_with_data
function.description:
Like g_array_sort(), but the comparison function receives an extra user data argument.
This is guaranteed to be a stable sort since version 2.32.
There used to be a comment here about making the sort stable by using the addresses of the elements in the comparison function. This did not actually work, so any such code should be removed.

function.name: g_array_unref
function.description:
Atomically decrements the reference count of @array by one. If the reference count drops to 0, all memory allocated by the array is released. This function is MT-safe and may be called from any thread.
Since: 2.22

function.name: g_ascii_digit_value
function.description: Determines the numeric value of a character as a decimal digit. Differs from g_unichar_digit_value() because it takes a char, so there's no worry about sign extension if characters are signed.
function.return: If @c is a decimal digit (according to g_ascii_isdigit()), its numeric value. Otherwise, -1.

function.name: g_ascii_dtostr
function.description:
Converts a #gdouble to a string, using the '.' as decimal point.
This function generates enough precision that converting the string back using g_ascii_strtod() gives the same machine-number (on machines with IEEE compatible 64bit doubles). It is guaranteed that the size of the resulting string will never be larger than @G_ASCII_DTOSTR_BUF_SIZE bytes.

parameter.name: buffer
parameter.parameter_description: A buffer to place the resulting string in

function.return: The pointer to the buffer with the converted string.

function.name: g_ascii_formatd
function.description:
Converts a #gdouble to a string, using the '.' as decimal point. To format the number you pass in a printf()-style format string. Allowed conversion specifiers are 'e', 'E', 'f', 'F', 'g' and 'G'.
If you just want to want to serialize the value into a string, use g_ascii_dtostr().

parameter.name: buffer
parameter.parameter_description: A buffer to place the resulting string in

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: The printf()-style format to use for the code to use for converting.

function.return: The pointer to the buffer with the converted string.

function.name: g_ascii_isalnum
function.description:
Determines whether a character is alphanumeric.
Unlike the standard C library isalnum() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII letters and ignores the locale, returning %FALSE for all non-ASCII characters. Also, unlike the standard library function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to cast to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII alphanumeric character

function.name: g_ascii_isalpha
function.description:
Determines whether a character is alphabetic (i.e. a letter).
Unlike the standard C library isalpha() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII letters and ignores the locale, returning %FALSE for all non-ASCII characters. Also, unlike the standard library function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to cast to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII alphabetic character

function.name: g_ascii_iscntrl
function.description:
Determines whether a character is a control character.
Unlike the standard C library iscntrl() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII control characters and ignores the locale, returning %FALSE for all non-ASCII characters. Also, unlike the standard library function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to cast to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII control character.

function.name: g_ascii_isdigit
function.description:
Determines whether a character is digit (0-9).
Unlike the standard C library isdigit() function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to cast to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII digit.

function.name: g_ascii_isgraph
function.description:
Determines whether a character is a printing character and not a space.
Unlike the standard C library isgraph() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII characters and ignores the locale, returning %FALSE for all non-ASCII characters. Also, unlike the standard library function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to cast to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII printing character other than space.

function.name: g_ascii_islower
function.description:
Determines whether a character is an ASCII lower case letter.
Unlike the standard C library islower() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII letters and ignores the locale, returning %FALSE for all non-ASCII characters. Also, unlike the standard library function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to worry about casting to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII lower case letter

function.name: g_ascii_isprint
function.description:
Determines whether a character is a printing character.
Unlike the standard C library isprint() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII characters and ignores the locale, returning %FALSE for all non-ASCII characters. Also, unlike the standard library function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to cast to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII printing character.

function.name: g_ascii_ispunct
function.description:
Determines whether a character is a punctuation character.
Unlike the standard C library ispunct() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII letters and ignores the locale, returning %FALSE for all non-ASCII characters. Also, unlike the standard library function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to cast to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII punctuation character.

function.name: g_ascii_isspace
function.description:
Determines whether a character is a white-space character.
Unlike the standard C library isspace() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII white-space and ignores the locale, returning %FALSE for all non-ASCII characters. Also, unlike the standard library function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to cast to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII white-space character

function.name: g_ascii_isupper
function.description:
Determines whether a character is an ASCII upper case letter.
Unlike the standard C library isupper() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII letters and ignores the locale, returning %FALSE for all non-ASCII characters. Also, unlike the standard library function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to worry about casting to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII upper case letter

function.name: g_ascii_isxdigit
function.description:
Determines whether a character is a hexadecimal-digit character.
Unlike the standard C library isxdigit() function, this takes a char, not an int, so don't call it on %EOF, but no need to cast to #guchar before passing a possibly non-ASCII character in.
function.return: %TRUE if @c is an ASCII hexadecimal-digit character.

function.name: g_ascii_strcasecmp
function.description:
Compare two strings, ignoring the case of ASCII characters.
Unlike the BSD strcasecmp() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII letters and ignores the locale, treating all non-ASCII bytes as if they are not letters.
This function should be used only on strings that are known to be in encodings where the bytes corresponding to ASCII letters always represent themselves. This includes UTF-8 and the ISO-8859-* charsets, but not for instance double-byte encodings like the Windows Codepage 932, where the trailing bytes of double-byte characters include all ASCII letters. If you compare two CP932 strings using this function, you will get false matches.
Both @s1 and @s2 must be non-%NULL.
function.return: 0 if the strings match, a negative value if @s1 < @s2, or a positive value if @s1 > @s2.

function.name: g_ascii_strdown
function.description: Converts all upper case ASCII letters to lower case ASCII letters.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of @str in bytes, or -1 if @str is nul-terminated

function.return: a newly-allocated string, with all the upper case characters in @str converted to lower case, with semantics that exactly match g_ascii_tolower(). (Note that this is unlike the old g_strdown(), which modified the string in place.)

function.name: g_ascii_strncasecmp
function.description:
Compare @s1 and @s2, ignoring the case of ASCII characters and any characters after the first @n in each string.
Unlike the BSD strcasecmp() function, this only recognizes standard ASCII letters and ignores the locale, treating all non-ASCII characters as if they are not letters.
The same warning as in g_ascii_strcasecmp() applies: Use this function only on strings known to be in encodings where bytes corresponding to ASCII letters always represent themselves.
function.return: 0 if the strings match, a negative value if @s1 < @s2, or a positive value if @s1 > @s2.

function.name: g_ascii_strtod
function.description:
Converts a string to a #gdouble value.
This function behaves like the standard strtod() function does in the C locale. It does this without actually changing the current locale, since that would not be thread-safe. A limitation of the implementation is that this function will still accept localized versions of infinities and NANs.
This function is typically used when reading configuration files or other non-user input that should be locale independent. To handle input from the user you should normally use the locale-sensitive system strtod() function.
To convert from a #gdouble to a string in a locale-insensitive way, use g_ascii_dtostr().
