Converts a pointer to a #gint to a hash value. It can be passed to g_hash_table_new() as the @hash_func parameter, when using non-%NULL pointers to integer values as keys in a #GHashTable.
Note that this function acts on pointers to #gint, not on #gint directly: if your hash table's keys are of the form `GINT_TO_POINTER (n)`, use g_direct_hash() instead.
function.return: a hash value corresponding to the key.

function.name: g_intern_static_string
function.description:
Returns a canonical representation for @string. Interned strings can be compared for equality by comparing the pointers, instead of using strcmp(). g_intern_static_string() does not copy the string, therefore @string must not be freed or modified.
Since: 2.10
function.return: a canonical representation for the string

function.name: g_intern_string
function.description:
Returns a canonical representation for @string. Interned strings can be compared for equality by comparing the pointers, instead of using strcmp().
Since: 2.10
function.return: a canonical representation for the string

function.name: g_io_add_watch
function.description: Adds the #GIOChannel into the default main loop context with the default priority.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call when the condition is satisfied

function.return: the event source id

function.name: g_io_add_watch_full
function.description:
Adds the #GIOChannel into the default main loop context with the given priority.
This internally creates a main loop source using g_io_create_watch() and attaches it to the main loop context with g_source_attach(). You can do these steps manually if you need greater control.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call when the condition is satisfied

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call when the source is removed

function.return: the event source id

function.name: g_io_channel_close
function.description:
Close an IO channel. Any pending data to be written will be flushed, ignoring errors. The channel will not be freed until the last reference is dropped using g_io_channel_unref().
Deprecated:2.2: Use g_io_channel_shutdown() instead.

function.name: g_io_channel_error_from_errno
function.description: Converts an `errno` error number to a #GIOChannelError.
function.return: a #GIOChannelError error number, e.g. %G_IO_CHANNEL_ERROR_INVAL.

function.name: g_io_channel_flush
function.description: Flushes the write buffer for the GIOChannel.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store an error of type #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation: One of #G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL, #G_IO_STATUS_AGAIN, or #G_IO_STATUS_ERROR.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_buffer_condition
function.description: This function returns a #GIOCondition depending on whether there is data to be read/space to write data in the internal buffers in the #GIOChannel. Only the flags %G_IO_IN and %G_IO_OUT may be set.
function.return: A #GIOCondition

function.name: g_io_channel_get_buffer_size
function.description: Gets the buffer size.
function.return: the size of the buffer.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_buffered
function.description: Returns whether @channel is buffered.
function.return: %TRUE if the @channel is buffered.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_close_on_unref
function.description: Returns whether the file/socket/whatever associated with @channel will be closed when @channel receives its final unref and is destroyed. The default value of this is %TRUE for channels created by g_io_channel_new_file (), and %FALSE for all other channels.
function.return: Whether the channel will be closed on the final unref of the GIOChannel data structure.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_encoding
function.description: Gets the encoding for the input/output of the channel. The internal encoding is always UTF-8. The encoding %NULL makes the channel safe for binary data.
function.return: A string containing the encoding, this string is owned by GLib and must not be freed.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_flags
function.description:
Gets the current flags for a #GIOChannel, including read-only flags such as %G_IO_FLAG_IS_READABLE.
The values of the flags %G_IO_FLAG_IS_READABLE and %G_IO_FLAG_IS_WRITABLE are cached for internal use by the channel when it is created. If they should change at some later point (e.g. partial shutdown of a socket with the UNIX shutdown() function), the user should immediately call g_io_channel_get_flags() to update the internal values of these flags.
function.return: the flags which are set on the channel

function.name: g_io_channel_get_line_term
function.description: This returns the string that #GIOChannel uses to determine where in the file a line break occurs. A value of %NULL indicates autodetection.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return the length of the line terminator

function.return: The line termination string. This value is owned by GLib and must not be freed.

function.name: g_io_channel_init
function.description:
Initializes a #GIOChannel struct.
This is called by each of the above functions when creating a #GIOChannel, and so is not often needed by the application programmer (unless you are creating a new type of #GIOChannel).

function.name: g_io_channel_new_file
function.description: Open a file @filename as a #GIOChannel using mode @mode. This channel will be closed when the last reference to it is dropped, so there is no need to call g_io_channel_close() (though doing so will not cause problems, as long as no attempt is made to access the channel after it is closed).

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: A string containing the name of a file

parameter.name: mode
parameter.parameter_description: One of "r", "w", "a", "r+", "w+", "a+". These have the same meaning as in fopen()

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: A location to return an error of type %G_FILE_ERROR

function.return: A #GIOChannel on success, %NULL on failure.

function.name: g_io_channel_read
function.description:
Reads data from a #GIOChannel.
Deprecated:2.2: Use g_io_channel_read_chars() instead.

parameter.name: buf
parameter.parameter_description: a buffer to read the data into (which should be at least count bytes long)

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to read from the #GIOChannel

parameter.name: bytes_read
parameter.parameter_description: returns the number of bytes actually read

function.return: %G_IO_ERROR_NONE if the operation was successful.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_chars
function.description: Replacement for g_io_channel_read() with the new API.

parameter.name: buf
parameter.parameter_description: a buffer to read data into

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the buffer. Note that the buffer may not be complelely filled even if there is data in the buffer if the remaining data is not a complete character.

parameter.name: bytes_read
parameter.parameter_description: The number of bytes read. This may be zero even on success if count < 6 and the channel's encoding is non-%NULL. This indicates that the next UTF-8 character is too wide for the buffer.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError.

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_line
function.description: Reads a line, including the terminating character(s), from a #GIOChannel into a newly-allocated string. @str_return will contain allocated memory if the return is %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL.

parameter.name: str_return
parameter.parameter_description: The line read from the #GIOChannel, including the line terminator. This data should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed. This is a nul-terminated string. If a @length of zero is returned, this will be %NULL instead.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: location to store length of the read data, or %NULL

parameter.name: terminator_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store position of line terminator, or %NULL

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: A location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_line_string
function.description: Reads a line from a #GIOChannel, using a #GString as a buffer.

parameter.name: buffer
parameter.parameter_description: a #GString into which the line will be written. If @buffer already contains data, the old data will be overwritten.

parameter.name: terminator_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store position of line terminator, or %NULL

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_to_end
function.description: Reads all the remaining data from the file.

parameter.name: str_return
parameter.parameter_description: Location to store a pointer to a string holding the remaining data in the #GIOChannel. This data should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed. This data is terminated by an extra nul character, but there may be other nuls in the intervening data.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: location to store length of the data

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL on success. This function never returns %G_IO_STATUS_EOF.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_unichar
function.description: Reads a Unicode character from @channel. This function cannot be called on a channel with %NULL encoding.

parameter.name: thechar
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return a character

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: a #GIOStatus

function.name: g_io_channel_ref
function.description: Increments the reference count of a #GIOChannel.
function.return: the @channel that was passed in (since 2.6)

function.name: g_io_channel_seek
function.description:
Sets the current position in the #GIOChannel, similar to the standard library function fseek().
Deprecated:2.2: Use g_io_channel_seek_position() instead.

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: an offset, in bytes, which is added to the position specified by @type

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the position in the file, which can be %G_SEEK_CUR (the current position), %G_SEEK_SET (the start of the file), or %G_SEEK_END (the end of the file)

function.return: %G_IO_ERROR_NONE if the operation was successful.

function.name: g_io_channel_seek_position
function.description: Replacement for g_io_channel_seek() with the new API.

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: The offset in bytes from the position specified by @type

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: a #GSeekType. The type %G_SEEK_CUR is only allowed in those cases where a call to g_io_channel_set_encoding () is allowed. See the documentation for g_io_channel_set_encoding () for details.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: A location to return an error of type #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_set_buffer_size
function.description: Sets the buffer size.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the buffer, or 0 to let GLib pick a good size

function.name: g_io_channel_set_buffered
function.description:
The buffering state can only be set if the channel's encoding is %NULL. For any other encoding, the channel must be buffered.
A buffered channel can only be set unbuffered if the channel's internal buffers have been flushed. Newly created channels or channels which have returned %G_IO_STATUS_EOF not require such a flush. For write-only channels, a call to g_io_channel_flush () is sufficient. For all other channels, the buffers may be flushed by a call to g_io_channel_seek_position (). This includes the possibility of seeking with seek type %G_SEEK_CUR and an offset of zero. Note that this means that socket-based channels cannot be set unbuffered once they have had data read from them.
On unbuffered channels, it is safe to mix read and write calls from the new and old APIs, if this is necessary for maintaining old code.
The default state of the channel is buffered.

parameter.name: buffered
parameter.parameter_description: whether to set the channel buffered or unbuffered

function.name: g_io_channel_set_close_on_unref
function.description: Setting this flag to %TRUE for a channel you have already closed can cause problems.

parameter.name: do_close
parameter.parameter_description: Whether to close the channel on the final unref of the GIOChannel data structure. The default value of this is %TRUE for channels created by g_io_channel_new_file (), and %FALSE for all other channels.

function.name: g_io_channel_set_encoding
function.description:
Sets the encoding for the input/output of the channel. The internal encoding is always UTF-8. The default encoding for the external file is UTF-8.
The encoding %NULL is safe to use with binary data.
The encoding can only be set if one of the following conditions is true:
- The channel was just created, and has not been written to or read from yet.
- The channel is write-only.
- The channel is a file, and the file pointer was just repositioned by a call to g_io_channel_seek_position(). (This flushes all the internal buffers.)
- The current encoding is %NULL or UTF-8.
- One of the (new API) read functions has just returned %G_IO_STATUS_EOF (or, in the case of g_io_channel_read_to_end(), %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL).
- One of the functions g_io_channel_read_chars() or g_io_channel_read_unichar() has returned %G_IO_STATUS_AGAIN or %G_IO_STATUS_ERROR. This may be useful in the case of %G_CONVERT_ERROR_ILLEGAL_SEQUENCE. Returning one of these statuses from g_io_channel_read_line(), g_io_channel_read_line_string(), or g_io_channel_read_to_end() does not guarantee that the encoding can be changed.
Channels which do not meet one of the above conditions cannot call g_io_channel_seek_position() with an offset of %G_SEEK_CUR, and, if they are "seekable", cannot call g_io_channel_write_chars() after calling one of the API "read" functions.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store an error of type #GConvertError

function.return: %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL if the encoding was successfully set

function.name: g_io_channel_set_flags
function.description: Sets the (writeable) flags in @channel to (@flags & %G_IO_FLAG_SET_MASK).

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: the flags to set on the IO channel

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: A location to return an error of type #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_set_line_term
function.description: This sets the string that #GIOChannel uses to determine where in the file a line break occurs.

parameter.name: line_term
parameter.parameter_description: The line termination string. Use %NULL for autodetect. Autodetection breaks on "\n", "\r\n", "\r", "\0", and the Unicode paragraph separator. Autodetection should not be used for anything other than file-based channels.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: The length of the termination string. If -1 is passed, the string is assumed to be nul-terminated. This option allows termination strings with embedded nuls.

function.name: g_io_channel_shutdown
function.description: Close an IO channel. Any pending data to be written will be flushed if @flush is %TRUE. The channel will not be freed until the last reference is dropped using g_io_channel_unref().
function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_unix_get_fd
function.description:
Returns the file descriptor of the #GIOChannel.
On Windows this function returns the file descriptor or socket of the #GIOChannel.
function.return: the file descriptor of the #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_unix_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GIOChannel given a file descriptor. On UNIX systems this works for plain files, pipes, and sockets.
The returned #GIOChannel has a reference count of 1.
The default encoding for #GIOChannel is UTF-8. If your application is reading output from a command using via pipe, you may need to set the encoding to the encoding of the current locale (see g_get_charset()) with the g_io_channel_set_encoding() function.
If you want to read raw binary data without interpretation, then call the g_io_channel_set_encoding() function with %NULL for the encoding argument.
This function is available in GLib on Windows, too, but you should avoid using it on Windows. The domain of file descriptors and sockets overlap. There is no way for GLib to know which one you mean in case the argument you pass to this function happens to be both a valid file descriptor and socket. If that happens a warning is issued, and GLib assumes that it is the file descriptor you mean.
function.return: a new #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_unref
function.description: Decrements the reference count of a #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_win32_new_fd
function.description:
Creates a new #GIOChannel given a file descriptor on Windows. This works for file descriptors from the C runtime.
This function works for file descriptors as returned by the open(), creat(), pipe() and fileno() calls in the Microsoft C runtime. In order to meaningfully use this function your code should use the same C runtime as GLib uses, which is msvcrt.dll. Note that in current Microsoft compilers it is near impossible to convince it to build code that would use msvcrt.dll. The last Microsoft compiler version that supported using msvcrt.dll as the C runtime was version 6. The GNU compiler and toolchain for Windows, also known as Mingw, fully supports msvcrt.dll.
If you have created a #GIOChannel for a file descriptor and started watching (polling) it, you shouldn't call read() on the file descriptor. This is because adding polling for a file descriptor is implemented in GLib on Windows by starting a thread that sits blocked in a read() from the file descriptor most of the time. All reads from the file descriptor should be done by this internal GLib thread. Your code should call only g_io_channel_read().
This function is available only in GLib on Windows.
function.return: a new #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_win32_new_messages
function.description:
Creates a new #GIOChannel given a window handle on Windows.
This function creates a #GIOChannel that can be used to poll for Windows messages for the window in question.
function.return: a new #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_win32_new_socket
function.description:
Creates a new #GIOChannel given a socket on Windows.
This function works for sockets created by Winsock. It's available only in GLib on Windows.
Polling a #GSource created to watch a channel for a socket puts the socket in non-blocking mode. This is a side-effect of the implementation and unavoidable.
function.return: a new #GIOChannel

function.name: g_io_channel_write
function.description:
Writes data to a #GIOChannel.
Deprecated:2.2: Use g_io_channel_write_chars() instead.

parameter.name: buf
parameter.parameter_description: the buffer containing the data to write

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to write

parameter.name: bytes_written
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes actually written

function.return: %G_IO_ERROR_NONE if the operation was successful.

function.name: g_io_channel_write_chars
function.description:
Replacement for g_io_channel_write() with the new API.
On seekable channels with encodings other than %NULL or UTF-8, generic mixing of reading and writing is not allowed. A call to g_io_channel_write_chars () may only be made on a channel from which data has been read in the cases described in the documentation for g_io_channel_set_encoding ().

parameter.name: buf
parameter.parameter_description: a buffer to write data from

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the buffer. If -1, the buffer is taken to be a nul-terminated string.

parameter.name: bytes_written
parameter.parameter_description: The number of bytes written. This can be nonzero even if the return value is not %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL. If the return value is %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL and the channel is blocking, this will always be equal to @count if @count >= 0.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_write_unichar
function.description: Writes a Unicode character to @channel. This function cannot be called on a channel with %NULL encoding.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: a #GIOStatus

function.name: g_io_create_watch
function.description:
Creates a #GSource that's dispatched when @condition is met for the given @channel. For example, if condition is #G_IO_IN, the source will be dispatched when there's data available for reading.
g_io_add_watch() is a simpler interface to this same functionality, for the case where you want to add the source to the default main loop context at the default priority.
On Windows, polling a #GSource created to watch a channel for a socket puts the socket in non-blocking mode. This is a side-effect of the implementation and unavoidable.
function.return: a new #GSource

function.name: g_key_file_free
function.description:
Clears all keys and groups from @key_file, and decreases the reference count by 1. If the reference count reaches zero, frees the key file and all its allocated memory.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_get_boolean
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as a boolean.
If @key cannot be found then %FALSE is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. Likewise, if the value associated with @key cannot be interpreted as a boolean then %FALSE is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_INVALID_VALUE.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the value associated with the key as a boolean, or %FALSE if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_boolean_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name as booleans.
If @key cannot be found then %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. Likewise, if the values associated with @key cannot be interpreted as booleans then %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_INVALID_VALUE.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the values associated with the key as a list of booleans, or %NULL if the key was not found or could not be parsed. The returned list of booleans should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_comment
function.return: a comment that should be freed with g_free()

function.name: g_key_file_get_double
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as a double. If @group_name is %NULL, the start_group is used.
If @key cannot be found then 0.0 is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. Likewise, if the value associated with @key cannot be interpreted as a double then 0.0 is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_INVALID_VALUE.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the value associated with the key as a double, or 0.0 if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_double_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name as doubles.
If @key cannot be found then %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. Likewise, if the values associated with @key cannot be interpreted as doubles then %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_INVALID_VALUE.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the values associated with the key as a list of doubles, or %NULL if the key was not found or could not be parsed. The returned list of doubles should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_groups
function.description:
Returns all groups in the key file loaded with @key_file. The array of returned groups will be %NULL-terminated, so @length may optionally be %NULL.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of returned groups, or %NULL

function.return: a newly-allocated %NULL-terminated array of strings. Use g_strfreev() to free it.

function.name: g_key_file_get_int64
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as a signed 64-bit integer. This is similar to g_key_file_get_integer() but can return 64-bit results without truncation.
Since: 2.26
function.return: the value associated with the key as a signed 64-bit integer, or 0 if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_integer
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as an integer.
If @key cannot be found then 0 is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. Likewise, if the value associated with @key cannot be interpreted as an integer then 0 is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_INVALID_VALUE.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the value associated with the key as an integer, or 0 if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_integer_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name as integers.
If @key cannot be found then %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. Likewise, if the values associated with @key cannot be interpreted as integers then %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_INVALID_VALUE.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the values associated with the key as a list of integers, or %NULL if the key was not found or could not be parsed. The returned list of integers should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_keys
function.description:
Returns all keys for the group name @group_name. The array of returned keys will be %NULL-terminated, so @length may optionally be %NULL. In the event that the @group_name cannot be found, %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_GROUP_NOT_FOUND.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of keys returned, or %NULL

function.return: a newly-allocated %NULL-terminated array of strings. Use g_strfreev() to free it.

function.name: g_key_file_get_locale_string
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name translated in the given @locale if available. If @locale is %NULL then the current locale is assumed.
If @key cannot be found then %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. If the value associated with @key cannot be interpreted or no suitable translation can be found then the untranslated value is returned.
Since: 2.6
function.return: a newly allocated string or %NULL if the specified key cannot be found.

function.name: g_key_file_get_locale_string_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name translated in the given @locale if available. If @locale is %NULL then the current locale is assumed.
If @key cannot be found then %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. If the values associated with @key cannot be interpreted or no suitable translations can be found then the untranslated values are returned. The returned array is %NULL-terminated, so @length may optionally be %NULL.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of returned strings or %NULL

function.return: a newly allocated %NULL-terminated string array or %NULL if the key isn't found. The string array should be freed with g_strfreev().

function.name: g_key_file_get_start_group
function.description:
Returns the name of the start group of the file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: The start group of the key file.

function.name: g_key_file_get_string
function.description:
Returns the string value associated with @key under @group_name. Unlike g_key_file_get_value(), this function handles escape sequences like \s.
In the event the key cannot be found, %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. In the event that the @group_name cannot be found, %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_GROUP_NOT_FOUND.
Since: 2.6
function.return: a newly allocated string or %NULL if the specified key cannot be found.

function.name: g_key_file_get_string_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name.
In the event the key cannot be found, %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. In the event that the @group_name cannot be found, %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_GROUP_NOT_FOUND.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of returned strings, or %NULL

function.return: a %NULL-terminated string array or %NULL if the specified key cannot be found. The array should be freed with g_strfreev().

function.name: g_key_file_get_uint64
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as an unsigned 64-bit integer. This is similar to g_key_file_get_integer() but can return large positive results without truncation.
Since: 2.26
function.return: the value associated with the key as an unsigned 64-bit integer, or 0 if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_value
function.description:
Returns the raw value associated with @key under @group_name. Use g_key_file_get_string() to retrieve an unescaped UTF-8 string.
In the event the key cannot be found, %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_KEY_NOT_FOUND. In the event that the @group_name cannot be found, %NULL is returned and @error is set to #G_KEY_FILE_ERROR_GROUP_NOT_FOUND.
Since: 2.6
function.return: a newly allocated string or %NULL if the specified key cannot be found.

function.name: g_key_file_has_group
function.description:
Looks whether the key file has the group @group_name.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if @group_name is a part of @key_file, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_key_file_has_key
function.description:
Looks whether the key file has the key @key in the group @group_name.
Note that this function does not follow the rules for #GError strictly; the return value both carries meaning and signals an error. To use this function, you must pass a #GError pointer in @error, and check whether it is not %NULL to see if an error occurred.
Language bindings should use g_key_file_get_value() to test whether or not a key exists.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if @key is a part of @group_name, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_load_from_data
function.description:
Loads a key file from memory into an empty #GKeyFile structure. If the object cannot be created then %error is set to a #GKeyFileError.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @data in bytes (or (gsize)-1 if data is nul-terminated)

function.return: %TRUE if a key file could be loaded, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_load_from_data_dirs
function.description:
This function looks for a key file named @file in the paths returned from g_get_user_data_dir() and g_get_system_data_dirs(), loads the file into @key_file and returns the file's full path in @full_path. If the file could not be loaded then an %error is set to either a #GFileError or #GKeyFileError.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: file
parameter.parameter_description: a relative path to a filename to open and parse

parameter.name: full_path
parameter.parameter_description: return location for a string containing the full path of the file, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if a key file could be loaded, %FALSE othewise

function.name: g_key_file_load_from_dirs
function.description:
This function looks for a key file named @file in the paths specified in @search_dirs, loads the file into @key_file and returns the file's full path in @full_path. If the file could not be loaded then an %error is set to either a #GFileError or #GKeyFileError.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: file
parameter.parameter_description: a relative path to a filename to open and parse

parameter.name: full_path
parameter.parameter_description: return location for a string containing the full path of the file, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if a key file could be loaded, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_load_from_file
function.description:
Loads a key file into an empty #GKeyFile structure. If the file could not be loaded then @error is set to either a #GFileError or #GKeyFileError.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: file
parameter.parameter_description: the path of a filename to load, in the GLib filename encoding

function.return: %TRUE if a key file could be loaded, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_new
function.description:
Creates a new empty #GKeyFile object. Use g_key_file_load_from_file(), g_key_file_load_from_data(), g_key_file_load_from_dirs() or g_key_file_load_from_data_dirs() to read an existing key file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: an empty #GKeyFile.

function.name: g_key_file_ref
function.description:
Increases the reference count of @key_file.
Since: 2.32
function.return: the same @key_file.

function.name: g_key_file_remove_comment
function.description:
Removes a comment above @key from @group_name. If @key is %NULL then @comment will be removed above @group_name. If both @key and @group_name are %NULL, then @comment will be removed above the first group in the file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if the comment was removed, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_remove_group
function.description:
Removes the specified group, @group_name, from the key file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if the group was removed, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_remove_key
function.description:
Removes @key in @group_name from the key file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if the key was removed, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_save_to_file
function.description:
Writes the contents of @key_file to @filename using g_file_set_contents().
This function can fail for any of the reasons that g_file_set_contents() may fail.
Since: 2.40

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the file to write to

function.return: %TRUE if successful, else %FALSE with @error set

function.name: g_key_file_set_boolean
function.description:
Associates a new boolean value with @key under @group_name. If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_boolean_list
function.description:
Associates a list of boolean values with @key under @group_name. If @key cannot be found then it is created. If @group_name is %NULL, the start_group is used.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_comment
function.description:
Places a comment above @key from @group_name. If @key is %NULL then @comment will be written above @group_name. If both @key and @group_name are %NULL, then @comment will be written above the first group in the file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: %TRUE if the comment was written, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_set_double
function.description:
Associates a new double value with @key under @group_name. If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.12

function.name: g_key_file_set_double_list
g_key_file_set_int64
function.description:
Associates a new integer value with @key under @group_name. If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_key_file_set_integer
function.description:
Associates a new integer value with @key under @group_name. If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_integer_list
function.description:
Associates a list of integer values with @key under @group_name. If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_list_separator
function.description:
Sets the character which is used to separate values in lists. Typically ';' or ',' are used as separators. The default list separator is ';'.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_locale_string
function.description:
Associates a string value for @key and @locale under @group_name. If the translation for @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_locale_string_list
function.description:
Associates a list of string values for @key and @locale under @group_name. If the translation for @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated array of locale string values

function.name: g_key_file_set_string
function.description:
Associates a new string value with @key under @group_name. If @key cannot be found then it is created. If @group_name cannot be found then it is created. Unlike g_key_file_set_value(), this function handles characters that need escaping, such as newlines.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_string_list
function.description:
Associates a list of string values for @key under @group_name. If @key cannot be found then it is created. If @group_name cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_uint64
function.description:
Associates a new integer value with @key under @group_name. If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_key_file_set_value
function.description:
Associates a new value with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created. If @group_name cannot be found then it is created. To set an UTF-8 string which may contain characters that need escaping (such as newlines or spaces), use g_key_file_set_string().
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_to_data
function.description:
This function outputs @key_file as a string.
Note that this function never reports an error, so it is safe to pass %NULL as @error.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the length of the returned string, or %NULL

function.return: a newly allocated string holding the contents of the #GKeyFile

function.name: g_key_file_unref
function.description:
Decreases the reference count of @key_file by 1. If the reference count reaches zero, frees the key file and all its allocated memory.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_list_alloc
function.description: Allocates space for one #GList element. It is called by g_list_append(), g_list_prepend(), g_list_insert() and g_list_insert_sorted() and so is rarely used on its own.
function.return: a pointer to the newly-allocated #GList element

function.name: g_list_append

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

function.return: either @list or the new start of the #GList if @list was %NULL

function.name: g_list_concat

parameter.name: list1
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: list2
parameter.parameter_description: the #GList to add to the end of the first #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the start of the new #GList, which equals @list1 if not %NULL

function.name: g_list_copy
function.description:
Copies a #GList.
Note that this is a "shallow" copy. If the list elements consist of pointers to data, the pointers are copied but the actual data is not. See g_list_copy_deep() if you need to copy the data as well.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the start of the new list that holds the same data as @list

function.name: g_list_copy_deep

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a copy function used to copy every element in the list

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the copy function @func, or %NULL

function.return: the start of the new list that holds a full copy of @list, use g_list_free_full() to free it

function.name: g_list_delete_link
function.description: Removes the node link_ from the list and frees it. Compare this to g_list_remove_link() which removes the node without freeing it.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_find
function.description: Finds the element in a #GList which contains the given data.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the found #GList element, or %NULL if it is not found

function.name: g_list_find_custom
function.description: Finds an element in a #GList, using a supplied function to find the desired element. It iterates over the list, calling the given function which should return 0 when the desired element is found. The function takes two #gconstpointer arguments, the #GList element's data as the first argument and the given user data.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the function

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each element. It should return 0 when the desired element is found

function.return: the found #GList element, or %NULL if it is not found

function.name: g_list_first
function.description: Gets the first element in a #GList.
function.return: the first element in the #GList, or %NULL if the #GList has no elements

function.name: g_list_foreach
function.description: Calls a function for each element of a #GList.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call with each element's data

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the function

function.name: g_list_free
function.description:
Frees all of the memory used by a #GList. The freed elements are returned to the slice allocator.
If list elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, you should either use g_list_free_full() or free them manually first.

function.name: g_list_free1
function.description: Another name for g_list_free_1().

function.name: g_list_free_1
function.description: Frees one #GList element. It is usually used after g_list_remove_link().

function.name: g_list_free_full
function.description:
Convenience method, which frees all the memory used by a #GList, and calls @free_func on every element's data.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: free_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to be called to free each element's data

function.name: g_list_index
function.description: Gets the position of the element containing the given data (starting from 0).

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the index of the element containing the data, or -1 if the data is not found

function.name: g_list_insert
function.description: Inserts a new element into the list at the given position.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position to insert the element. If this is negative, or is larger than the number of elements in the list, the new element is added on to the end of the list.

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_insert_before
function.description: Inserts a new element into the list before the given position.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: the list element before which the new element is inserted or %NULL to insert at the end of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_insert_sorted
function.description:
Inserts a new element into the list, using the given comparison function to determine its position.
If you are adding many new elements to a list, and the number of new elements is much larger than the length of the list, use g_list_prepend() to add the new items and sort the list afterwards with g_list_sort().

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the already sorted list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to compare elements in the list. It should return a number > 0 if the first parameter comes after the second parameter in the sort order.

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_insert_sorted_with_data
function.description:
Inserts a new element into the list, using the given comparison function to determine its position.
If you are adding many new elements to a list, and the number of new elements is much larger than the length of the list, use g_list_prepend() to add the new items and sort the list afterwards with g_list_sort().
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the already sorted list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to compare elements in the list. It should return a number > 0 if the first parameter comes after the second parameter in the sort order.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to comparison function

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_last
function.description: Gets the last element in a #GList.
function.return: the last element in the #GList, or %NULL if the #GList has no elements

function.name: g_list_length
function.description:
Gets the number of elements in a #GList.
This function iterates over the whole list to count its elements. Use a #GQueue instead of a GList if you regularly need the number of items.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the number of elements in the #GList

function.name: g_list_next
function.return: the next element, or %NULL if there are no more elements

function.name: g_list_nth
function.description: Gets the element at the given position in a #GList.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: n
parameter.parameter_description: the position of the element, counting from 0

function.return: the element, or %NULL if the position is off the end of the #GList

function.name: g_list_nth_data
function.description: Gets the data of the element at the given position.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the element's data, or %NULL if the position is off the end of the #GList

function.name: g_list_nth_prev
function.description: Gets the element @n places before @list.

parameter.name: n
parameter.parameter_description: the position of the element, counting from 0

function.return: the element, or %NULL if the position is off the end of the #GList

function.name: g_list_position
function.description: Gets the position of the given element in the #GList (starting from 0).

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the position of the element in the #GList, or -1 if the element is not found

function.name: g_list_prepend

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

function.return: a pointer to the newly prepended element, which is the new start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_previous
function.return: the previous element, or %NULL if there are no previous elements

function.name: g_list_remove
function.description: Removes an element from a #GList. If two elements contain the same data, only the first is removed. If none of the elements contain the data, the #GList is unchanged.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data of the element to remove

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_remove_all
function.description: Removes all list nodes with data equal to @data. Returns the new head of the list. Contrast with g_list_remove() which removes only the first node matching the given data.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_remove_link

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_reverse
function.description: Reverses a #GList. It simply switches the next and prev pointers of each element.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the start of the reversed #GList

function.name: g_list_sort
function.description: Sorts a #GList using the given comparison function. The algorithm used is a stable sort.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: compare_func
parameter.parameter_description: the comparison function used to sort the #GList. This function is passed the data from 2 elements of the #GList and should return 0 if they are equal, a negative value if the first element comes before the second, or a positive value if the first element comes after the second.

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_sort_with_data
function.description: Like g_list_sort(), but the comparison function accepts a user data argument.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to comparison function

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_listenv
function.description:
Gets the names of all variables set in the environment.
Programs that want to be portable to Windows should typically use this function and g_getenv() instead of using the environ array from the C library directly. On Windows, the strings in the environ array are in system codepage encoding, while in most of the typical use cases for environment variables in GLib-using programs you want the UTF-8 encoding that this function and g_getenv() provide.
Since: 2.8
function.return: a %NULL-terminated list of strings which must be freed with g_strfreev().

function.name: g_locale_from_utf8
function.description: Converts a string from UTF-8 to the encoding used for strings by the C runtime (usually the same as that used by the operating system) in the [current locale][setlocale]. On Windows this means the system codepage.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the string, or -1 if the string is nul-terminated (Note that some encodings may allow nul bytes to occur inside strings. In that case, using -1 for the @len parameter is unsafe)

parameter.name: bytes_read
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the number of bytes in the input string that were successfully converted, or %NULL. Even if the conversion was successful, this may be less than @len if there were partial characters at the end of the input. If the error #G_CONVERT_ERROR_ILLEGAL_SEQUENCE occurs, the value stored will the byte offset after the last valid input sequence.

parameter.name: bytes_written
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes stored in the output buffer (not including the terminating nul).

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore errors. Any of the errors in #GConvertError may occur.

function.return: A newly-allocated buffer containing the converted string, or %NULL on an error, and error will be set.

function.name: g_locale_to_utf8
function.description: Converts a string which is in the encoding used for strings by the C runtime (usually the same as that used by the operating system) in the [current locale][setlocale] into a UTF-8 string.

parameter.name: opsysstring
parameter.parameter_description: a string in the encoding of the current locale. On Windows this means the system codepage.

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the string, or -1 if the string is nul-terminated (Note that some encodings may allow nul bytes to occur inside strings. In that case, using -1 for the @len parameter is unsafe)

parameter.name: bytes_read
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the number of bytes in the input string that were successfully converted, or %NULL. Even if the conversion was successful, this may be less than @len if there were partial characters at the end of the input. If the error #G_CONVERT_ERROR_ILLEGAL_SEQUENCE occurs, the value stored will the byte offset after the last valid input sequence.

parameter.name: bytes_written
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes stored in the output buffer (not including the terminating nul).

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore errors. Any of the errors in #GConvertError may occur.

function.return: A newly-allocated buffer containing the converted string, or %NULL on an error, and error will be set.

function.name: g_log
function.description:
Logs an error or debugging message.
If the log level has been set as fatal, the abort() function is called to terminate the program.
If g_log_default_handler() is used as the log handler function, a new-line character will automatically be appended to @..., and need not be entered manually.

parameter.name: log_level
parameter.parameter_description: the log level, either from #GLogLevelFlags or a user-defined level

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the message format. See the printf() documentation

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the parameters to insert into the format string

function.name: g_log_default_handler
function.description:
The default log handler set up by GLib; g_log_set_default_handler() allows to install an alternate default log handler. This is used if no log handler has been set for the particular log domain and log level combination. It outputs the message to stderr or stdout and if the log level is fatal it calls abort(). It automatically prints a new-line character after the message, so one does not need to be manually included in @message.
The behavior of this log handler can be influenced by a number of environment variables:
- `G_MESSAGES_PREFIXED`: A :-separated list of log levels for which messages should be prefixed by the program name and PID of the aplication.
- `G_MESSAGES_DEBUG`: A space-separated list of log domains for which debug and informational messages are printed. By default these messages are not printed.
stderr is used for levels %G_LOG_LEVEL_ERROR, %G_LOG_LEVEL_CRITICAL, %G_LOG_LEVEL_WARNING and %G_LOG_LEVEL_MESSAGE. stdout is used for the rest.

parameter.name: log_domain
parameter.parameter_description: the log domain of the message

parameter.name: unused_data
parameter.parameter_description: data passed from g_log() which is unused

function.name: g_log_remove_handler
function.description: Removes the log handler.

parameter.name: handler_id
parameter.parameter_description: the id of the handler, which was returned in g_log_set_handler()

function.name: g_log_set_always_fatal
function.description:
Sets the message levels which are always fatal, in any log domain. When a message with any of these levels is logged the program terminates. You can only set the levels defined by GLib to be fatal. %G_LOG_LEVEL_ERROR is always fatal.
You can also make some message levels fatal at runtime by setting the `G_DEBUG` environment variable (see [Running GLib Applications](glib-running.html)).

parameter.name: fatal_mask
parameter.parameter_description: the mask containing bits set for each level of error which is to be fatal

function.return: the old fatal mask

function.name: g_log_set_default_handler
function.description:
Installs a default log handler which is used if no log handler has been set for the particular log domain and log level combination. By default, GLib uses g_log_default_handler() as default log handler.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: data passed to the log handler

function.return: the previous default log handler

function.name: g_log_set_fatal_mask
function.description: Sets the log levels which are fatal in the given domain. %G_LOG_LEVEL_ERROR is always fatal.
function.return: the old fatal mask for the log domain

function.name: g_log_set_handler
function.description:
Sets the log handler for a domain and a set of log levels. To handle fatal and recursive messages the @log_levels parameter must be combined with the #G_LOG_FLAG_FATAL and #G_LOG_FLAG_RECURSION bit flags.
Note that since the #G_LOG_LEVEL_ERROR log level is always fatal, if you want to set a handler for this log level you must combine it with #G_LOG_FLAG_FATAL.
Here is an example for adding a log handler for all warning messages in the default domain: |[<!-- language="C" --> g_log_set_handler (NULL, G_LOG_LEVEL_WARNING | G_LOG_FLAG_FATAL | G_LOG_FLAG_RECURSION, my_log_handler, NULL); ]|
This example adds a log handler for all critical messages from GTK+: |[<!-- language="C" --> g_log_set_handler ("Gtk", G_LOG_LEVEL_CRITICAL | G_LOG_FLAG_FATAL | G_LOG_FLAG_RECURSION, my_log_handler, NULL); ]|
This example adds a log handler for all messages from GLib: |[<!-- language="C" --> g_log_set_handler ("GLib", G_LOG_LEVEL_MASK | G_LOG_FLAG_FATAL | G_LOG_FLAG_RECURSION, my_log_handler, NULL); ]|

parameter.name: log_domain
parameter.parameter_description: the log domain, or %NULL for the default "" application domain

parameter.name: log_levels
parameter.parameter_description: the log levels to apply the log handler for. To handle fatal and recursive messages as well, combine the log levels with the #G_LOG_FLAG_FATAL and #G_LOG_FLAG_RECURSION bit flags.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: data passed to the log handler

function.return: the id of the new handler

function.name: g_logv
function.description:
Logs an error or debugging message.
If the log level has been set as fatal, the abort() function is called to terminate the program.
If g_log_default_handler() is used as the log handler function, a new-line character will automatically be appended to @..., and need not be entered manually.

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the message format. See the printf() documentation

parameter.name: args
parameter.parameter_description: the parameters to insert into the format string

function.name: g_lstat
function.description:
A wrapper for the POSIX lstat() function. The lstat() function is like stat() except that in the case of symbolic links, it returns information about the symbolic link itself and not the file that it refers to. If the system does not support symbolic links g_lstat() is identical to g_stat().
See your C library manual for more details about lstat().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding (UTF-8 on Windows)

parameter.name: buf
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a stat struct, which will be filled with the file information

function.return: 0 if the information was successfully retrieved, -1 if an error occurred

function.name: g_main_context_acquire
function.description:
Tries to become the owner of the specified context. If some other thread is the owner of the context, returns %FALSE immediately. Ownership is properly recursive: the owner can require ownership again and will release ownership when g_main_context_release() is called as many times as g_main_context_acquire().
You must be the owner of a context before you can call g_main_context_prepare(), g_main_context_query(), g_main_context_check(), g_main_context_dispatch().
function.return: %TRUE if the operation succeeded, and this thread is now the owner of @context.

function.name: g_main_context_add_poll
function.description: Adds a file descriptor to the set of file descriptors polled for this context. This will very seldom be used directly. Instead a typical event source will use g_source_add_unix_fd() instead.

parameter.name: fd
parameter.parameter_description: a #GPollFD structure holding information about a file descriptor to watch.

parameter.name: priority
parameter.parameter_description: the priority for this file descriptor which should be the same as the priority used for g_source_attach() to ensure that the file descriptor is polled whenever the results may be needed.

function.name: g_main_context_check
function.description:
Passes the results of polling back to the main loop.
You must have successfully acquired the context with g_main_context_acquire() before you may call this function.

parameter.name: max_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the maximum numerical priority of sources to check

parameter.name: fds
parameter.parameter_description: array of #GPollFD's that was passed to the last call to g_main_context_query()

function.return: %TRUE if some sources are ready to be dispatched.

function.name: g_main_context_default
function.description: Returns the global default main context. This is the main context used for main loop functions when a main loop is not explicitly specified, and corresponds to the "main" main loop. See also g_main_context_get_thread_default().
function.return: the global default main context.

function.name: g_main_context_dispatch
function.description:
Dispatches all pending sources.
You must have successfully acquired the context with g_main_context_acquire() before you may call this function.

function.name: g_main_context_find_source_by_funcs_user_data
function.description: Finds a source with the given source functions and user data. If multiple sources exist with the same source function and user data, the first one found will be returned.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMainContext (if %NULL, the default context will be used).

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the user data from the callback.

function.return: the source, if one was found, otherwise %NULL

function.name: g_main_context_find_source_by_id
function.description:
Finds a #GSource given a pair of context and ID.
It is a programmer error to attempt to lookup a non-existent source.
More specifically: source IDs can be reissued after a source has been destroyed and therefore it is never valid to use this function with a source ID which may have already been removed. An example is when scheduling an idle to run in another thread with g_idle_add(): the idle may already have run and been removed by the time this function is called on its (now invalid) source ID. This source ID may have been reissued, leading to the operation being performed against the wrong source.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMainContext (if %NULL, the default context will be used)

parameter.name: source_id
parameter.parameter_description: the source ID, as returned by g_source_get_id().

function.return: the #GSource

function.name: g_main_context_find_source_by_user_data
function.description: Finds a source with the given user data for the callback. If multiple sources exist with the same user data, the first one found will be returned.
function.return: the source, if one was found, otherwise %NULL

function.name: g_main_context_get_poll_func
function.description: Gets the poll function set by g_main_context_set_poll_func().
function.return: the poll function

function.name: g_main_context_get_thread_default
function.description:
Gets the thread-default #GMainContext for this thread. Asynchronous operations that want to be able to be run in contexts other than the default one should call this method or g_main_context_ref_thread_default() to get a #GMainContext to add their #GSources to. (Note that even in single-threaded programs applications may sometimes want to temporarily push a non-default context, so it is not safe to assume that this will always return %NULL if you are running in the default thread.)
If you need to hold a reference on the context, use g_main_context_ref_thread_default() instead.
Since: 2.22
function.return: the thread-default #GMainContext, or %NULL if the thread-default context is the global default context.

function.name: g_main_context_invoke
function.description:
Invokes a function in such a way that @context is owned during the invocation of @function.
If @context is %NULL then the global default main context as returned by g_main_context_default() is used.
If @context is owned by the current thread, @function is called directly. Otherwise, if @context is the thread-default main context of the current thread and g_main_context_acquire() succeeds, then @function is called and g_main_context_release() is called afterwards.
In any other case, an idle source is created to call @function and that source is attached to @context (presumably to be run in another thread). The idle source is attached with #G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT priority. If you want a different priority, use g_main_context_invoke_full().
Note that, as with normal idle functions, @function should probably return %FALSE. If it returns %TRUE, it will be continuously run in a loop (and may prevent this call from returning).
Since: 2.28

function.name: g_main_context_invoke_full
function.description:
Invokes a function in such a way that @context is owned during the invocation of @function.
This function is the same as g_main_context_invoke() except that it lets you specify the priority incase @function ends up being scheduled as an idle and also lets you give a #GDestroyNotify for @data.
@notify should not assume that it is called from any particular thread or with any particular context acquired.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: priority
parameter.parameter_description: the priority at which to run @function

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call when @data is no longer in use, or %NULL.

function.name: g_main_context_is_owner
function.description:
Determines whether this thread holds the (recursive) ownership of this #GMainContext. This is useful to know before waiting on another thread that may be blocking to get ownership of @context.
Since: 2.10
function.return: %TRUE if current thread is owner of @context.

function.name: g_main_context_iteration
function.description:
Runs a single iteration for the given main loop. This involves checking to see if any event sources are ready to be processed, then if no events sources are ready and @may_block is %TRUE, waiting for a source to become ready, then dispatching the highest priority events sources that are ready. Otherwise, if @may_block is %FALSE sources are not waited to become ready, only those highest priority events sources will be dispatched (if any), that are ready at this given moment without further waiting.
Note that even when @may_block is %TRUE, it is still possible for g_main_context_iteration() to return %FALSE, since the wait may be interrupted for other reasons than an event source becoming ready.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMainContext (if %NULL, the default context will be used)

function.return: %TRUE if events were dispatched.

function.name: g_main_context_new
function.description: Creates a new #GMainContext structure.
function.return: the new #GMainContext

function.name: g_main_context_pending
function.description: Checks if any sources have pending events for the given context.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMainContext (if %NULL, the default context will be used)

function.return: %TRUE if events are pending.

function.name: g_main_context_pop_thread_default
function.description:
Pops @context off the thread-default context stack (verifying that it was on the top of the stack).
Since: 2.22

function.name: g_main_context_prepare
function.description:
Prepares to poll sources within a main loop. The resulting information for polling is determined by calling g_main_context_query ().
You must have successfully acquired the context with g_main_context_acquire() before you may call this function.

parameter.name: priority
parameter.parameter_description: location to store priority of highest priority source already ready.

function.return: %TRUE if some source is ready to be dispatched prior to polling.

function.name: g_main_context_push_thread_default
function.description:
Acquires @context and sets it as the thread-default context for the current thread. This will cause certain asynchronous operations (such as most [gio][gio]-based I/O) which are started in this thread to run under @context and deliver their results to its main loop, rather than running under the global default context in the main thread. Note that calling this function changes the context returned by g_main_context_get_thread_default(), not the one returned by g_main_context_default(), so it does not affect the context used by functions like g_idle_add().
Normally you would call this function shortly after creating a new thread, passing it a #GMainContext which will be run by a #GMainLoop in that thread, to set a new default context for all async operations in that thread. (In this case, you don't need to ever call g_main_context_pop_thread_default().) In some cases however, you may want to schedule a single operation in a non-default context, or temporarily use a non-default context in the main thread. In that case, you can wrap the call to the asynchronous operation inside a g_main_context_push_thread_default() / g_main_context_pop_thread_default() pair, but it is up to you to ensure that no other asynchronous operations accidentally get started while the non-default context is active.
Beware that libraries that predate this function may not correctly handle being used from a thread with a thread-default context. Eg, see g_file_supports_thread_contexts().
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMainContext, or %NULL for the global default context

function.name: g_main_context_query
function.description:
Determines information necessary to poll this main loop.
You must have successfully acquired the context with g_main_context_acquire() before you may call this function.

parameter.name: timeout_
parameter.parameter_description: location to store timeout to be used in polling

parameter.name: fds
parameter.parameter_description: location to store #GPollFD records that need to be polled.

function.return: the number of records actually stored in @fds, or, if more than @n_fds records need to be stored, the number of records that need to be stored.

function.name: g_main_context_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count on a #GMainContext object by one.
function.return: the @context that was passed in (since 2.6)

function.name: g_main_context_ref_thread_default
function.description:
Gets the thread-default #GMainContext for this thread, as with g_main_context_get_thread_default(), but also adds a reference to it with g_main_context_ref(). In addition, unlike g_main_context_get_thread_default(), if the thread-default context is the global default context, this will return that #GMainContext (with a ref added to it) rather than returning %NULL.
Since: 2.32
function.return: the thread-default #GMainContext. Unref with g_main_context_unref() when you are done with it.

function.name: g_main_context_release
function.description: Releases ownership of a context previously acquired by this thread with g_main_context_acquire(). If the context was acquired multiple times, the ownership will be released only when g_main_context_release() is called as many times as it was acquired.

function.name: g_main_context_remove_poll
function.description: Removes file descriptor from the set of file descriptors to be polled for a particular context.

parameter.name: fd
parameter.parameter_description: a #GPollFD descriptor previously added with g_main_context_add_poll()

function.name: g_main_context_set_poll_func
function.description:
Sets the function to use to handle polling of file descriptors. It will be used instead of the poll() system call (or GLib's replacement function, which is used where poll() isn't available).
This function could possibly be used to integrate the GLib event loop with an external event loop.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call to poll all file descriptors

function.name: g_main_context_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count on a #GMainContext object by one. If the result is zero, free the context and free all associated memory.

function.name: g_main_context_wait
function.description: Tries to become the owner of the specified context, as with g_main_context_acquire(). But if another thread is the owner, atomically drop @mutex and wait on @cond until that owner releases ownership or until @cond is signaled, then try again (once) to become the owner.
function.return: %TRUE if the operation succeeded, and this thread is now the owner of @context.

function.name: g_main_context_wakeup
g_main_current_source
function.description:
Returns the currently firing source for this thread.
Since: 2.12
function.return: The currently firing source or %NULL.

function.name: g_main_depth
function.return: The main loop recursion level in the current thread

function.name: g_main_destroy
function.description:
Frees the memory allocated for the #GMainLoop.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_main_loop_unref() instead

function.name: g_main_is_running
function.description:
Checks if the main loop is running.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_main_loop_is_running() instead
function.return: %TRUE if the main loop is running

function.name: g_main_iteration
function.description:
Runs a single iteration for the default #GMainContext.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_main_context_iteration() instead.

parameter.name: may_block
parameter.parameter_description: set to %TRUE if it should block (i.e. wait) until an event source becomes ready. It will return after an event source has been processed. If set to %FALSE it will return immediately if no event source is ready to be processed.

function.return: %TRUE if more events are pending.

function.name: g_main_loop_get_context
function.description: Returns the #GMainContext of @loop.
function.return: the #GMainContext of @loop

function.name: g_main_loop_is_running
function.description: Checks to see if the main loop is currently being run via g_main_loop_run().
function.return: %TRUE if the mainloop is currently being run.

function.name: g_main_loop_new
function.description: Creates a new #GMainLoop structure.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMainContext (if %NULL, the default context will be used).

parameter.name: is_running
parameter.parameter_description: set to %TRUE to indicate that the loop is running. This is not very important since calling g_main_loop_run() will set this to %TRUE anyway.

function.return: a new #GMainLoop.

function.name: g_main_loop_quit
function.description:
Stops a #GMainLoop from running. Any calls to g_main_loop_run() for the loop will return.
Note that sources that have already been dispatched when g_main_loop_quit() is called will still be executed.

function.name: g_main_loop_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count on a #GMainLoop object by one.
function.return: @loop

function.name: g_main_loop_run
function.description: Runs a main loop until g_main_loop_quit() is called on the loop. If this is called for the thread of the loop's #GMainContext, it will process events from the loop, otherwise it will simply wait.

function.name: g_main_loop_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count on a #GMainLoop object by one. If the result is zero, free the loop and free all associated memory.

function.name: g_main_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GMainLoop for th default main context.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_main_loop_new() instead

parameter.name: is_running
parameter.parameter_description: set to %TRUE to indicate that the loop is running. This is not very important since calling g_main_run() will set this to %TRUE anyway.

function.return: a new #GMainLoop

function.name: g_main_pending
function.description: Checks if any events are pending for the default #GMainContext (i.e. ready to be processed).
function.return:
%TRUE if any events are pending.
Deprected: 2.2: Use g_main_context_pending() instead.

function.name: g_main_quit
function.description:
Stops the #GMainLoop. If g_main_run() was called to run the #GMainLoop, it will now return.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_main_loop_quit() instead

function.name: g_main_run
function.description:
Runs a main loop until it stops running.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_main_loop_run() instead

function.name: g_main_set_poll_func
function.description:
Sets the function to use for the handle polling of file descriptors for the default main context.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_main_context_set_poll_func() again

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call to poll all file descriptors

function.name: g_malloc
function.description: Allocates @n_bytes bytes of memory. If @n_bytes is 0 it returns %NULL.

parameter.name: n_bytes
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to allocate

function.return: a pointer to the allocated memory

function.name: g_malloc0
